Each room is interesting to unlock and explore‚Ä¶ the first time, at least.- Decent replay value thanks to multiple endings and different possible paths to take.- Logical environmental interaction that plays out in a plausible way using the items at hand.- Tremendously unfair death-related mechanics designed to kill in ways you can‚Äôt possibly anticipate the first time. This creates ‚Äòfiller content‚Äô via backtracking, since the world resets on each death.- Generic storyline, mediocre writing of lore documents. Nothing feels original or interesting at any point, the decent premise devolves into ‚Äòyet another horror‚Äô very quickly.- Obnoxious voiced protagonist, who speaks the same lines endlessly and describes items in a flat, irritating, out-of-place tone that completely ruins the atmosphere.- Poor MKB support. Mouse usage is limited to aiming / looking around, all menus need to be navigated with Arrow Keys or WASD without key rebinding. Unacceptable for a 2022 PC release.- Inability to discard / delete unwanted or useless items: you‚Äôll have to run back at a stash each time, or use an item if possible, to make room.üü® Bugs & Issuesüîß Specs- Some distortion effects, like film grain or film bands, can‚Äôt be turned off.- Enemies can spawn very close to transitions / doors, and become a guaranteed damage source you can‚Äôt avoid in time.- 3900X- 2080Ti- 32GB RAM- SSD- 1440pContent & Replay Value:It took me around 4 hours to get one of the endings. Playtime may vary greatly depending on number of deaths (resets). Replay value is decent: depending on certain actions and the number of deaths you will unlock different endings and situations, however most of the game will remain the same nonetheless.Is it worth buying?No. Not only the price tag of 20‚Ç¨ is rather steep for 4 hours plus additional runs (that will take much less, given your acquired knowledge), but the outlined issues deal a severe blow to any and all enjoyment. Move on to better survival horrors, there‚Äôs plenty around.Verdict: BadRating Chart HereA poorly-executed survival horror that relies on annoying mechanics to stretch content, alongside an obnoxious protagonist and a forgettable story.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2832333700In-DepthPremise, Setting & WritingNaked and terrified, you‚Äôll wake up in a bathtub full of bloodied water. You don‚Äôt have the slightest idea of what happened, and now you‚Äôre locked in a motel bathroom. After getting your bearings and finding a way out, you‚Äôll soon understand things aren‚Äôt alright at all in this decrepit, half-totaled motel, between unearthly screams and horrendous abominations that roam the locales.Most of Oxide is set in a three-story motel under renovation. The horror feeling is kinda there, with most premises being dark, damp, foggy and eerie, as well compounded by an audio compartment that does the job well enough. Too bad this is all ruined by Matt (as in, you) constantly stating ‚Äúhe needs to get out‚Äù, or describing events / items with a tone as robotic as a train station‚Äôs automated announcer. Some classic ‚Äòcheap jumpscares‚Äô are added to the mix at times, and they fail to impress.Numerous lore documents pertaining to yourself, or other relevant characters, can be found in the furniture, on the ground and generally all over the place. Each of the writers is distinct enough in their tone, however the content itself feels quite clich√®d and just doesn‚Äôt hook you the right way at any point. ‚ÄúMad scientist doing crazy experiments‚Äù trope? Check! ‚ÄúGuy who lost humanity and now is on a vengeance‚Äù? Sure! ‚ÄúToken female character that doesn‚Äôt know what the hell to do‚Äù? Yep! Horror tropes 101, everyone.Exploration & PuzzlesYour primary goal will be opening as many rooms as you can, in the hopes of finding a way to the third floor‚Äôs common areas, the only exit still available. Think of each room as a self-contained mini-puzzle, as most of them will have one or more items to interact with, that often require you figuring out a specific item order, a code, or the right item to use between several. There is always a right way and several wrong ways to get something done, the latter ones often inflicting you a detrimental status effect, or killing you instantly in a few cases.The main issue is that in many instances, not only is there no clear way to figure out what‚Äôs right or wrong, but you‚Äôll also be actively deceived by Oxide itself. For example, I found the number ‚Äú15‚Äù behind a closet, and said to myself ‚Äúthat must be the correct vial, among five, i have to pick for this puzzle!‚Äù - nope, I got poisoned and died instead. Expect this to happen numerous times, and if you ran out of supplies, well‚Ä¶ goodbye!Exploring the premises will indeed net you a modest number of consumables, like bandages or antidotes, vital to clear the effects that otherwise become lethal in around 30-40 seconds or so. Even by collecting all of them, there‚Äôll be no way in Hell you‚Äôll be able to get out alive on your first run: too many shenanigans you can‚Äôt predict.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2832658783Combat & Inventory ManagementYour trusty revolver will be the only means of defense against the horrors. Bullets are a fairly common finding, and most enemies take five to vanquish. It's a simple point-and-shoot affair, with a small quick time event to free yourself from an enemy‚Äôs grab, and no other particular mechanic, since all except one enemy are static threats. It has to be noted enemies have a detection system, some of them can be ‚Äòstealthed‚Äô but this is inconsistent - most will just spawn and target you immediately after certain interactions, though.Up to nine inventory slots can be gained, via some items found in the various rooms. This is very limited compared to the amount of  unique stuff you‚Äôll find (like keys), but the shared stashes alleviate part of the issue by letting you deposit items for later use, and retrieve them at any time. And yet, expect to backtrack back and forth numerous times for this.Death-related MechanicsSo, what happens exactly when you die? Don‚Äôt worry, I'll now explain to you the peak of game design we have to deal with here. Upon your demise, a story-related cutscene will play, different each time, and you‚Äôll be back to square one at the bathtub. Everything has been reset: stash, inventory, upgrades, doors are locked again. Some things changed, though: certain enemy spawn have been altered, and on later deaths more foes will spawn, like poison plants. Most item spawns remain the same, except for a very few that change slightly. This would be fine and interesting if implemented properly - not the case here.The thing is, nothing major changes with death, apart from more enemies to deal with and the ending you‚Äôll get. You‚Äôll have to do the exact same things again twice, thrice, etc. - each time with added annoyances. This becomes tedious, boring very soon, and given the game kills you in unpredictable ways as explained before, this creates a perfect storm of frustration. Don‚Äôt think of this as ‚Äòold school‚Äô because it isn‚Äôt, it‚Äôs simply badly designed.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2832658863

The content is entirely linear, there‚Äôs no reason to replay once finished.Is it worth buying?The standard price of 30‚Ç¨ (3‚Ç¨ / hour of playtime) is still a bit steep for this amount of content, despite the good quality offered. I‚Äôd recommend waiting for a small discount before buying.Verdict: Very GoodRating Chart HereA high-quality narrative adventure with a setting that proves novel, historically-accurate and interesting. Some moderate issues prevent it from realizing its full potential.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2830781616In-DepthPremise, Setting & Writing1944. Italy is ravaged by the misery of war, with Allied forces moving up towards the Tuscany region while Axis troops mount a desperate defense. Protagonist Giulia K. is the daughter of a high-profile Nazi officer, but even this privileged position doesn‚Äôt save her from tragedy. One day, her twin sister Martha is found dead in a lake - an overwhelming loss. She always was her parents‚Äô favorite, unlike Giulia, so the latter decides to take her identity, pretending to be her from that moment forward, to gain the love so far denied to her.MiD mostly takes place in and around a countryside villa outside the village of San Casciano, Tuscany. There‚Äôs a remarkable attention to detail in the realization of each location, from the interiors of a typical upper-class 1940 Italian household, with luxuries such as electric power and a phone line, to the verdant woods and sun-beaten dirt paths commonly seen in the rural areas of the region even today. The marked contrast between these idyllic landscapes and the brutality of war, or the horrifying visions in Giulia‚Äôs mind, creates a rollercoaster of varied atmospheres that works out very well.Apart from the protagonist, there‚Äôs a small roster of relevant characters that, however, never happen to dialogue directly with you at any point: a consequence of the recent events, and of the pretense Giulia decided to put up. You‚Äôll hear conversations, read missives, listen to telephone calls, but never engage in active dialogues save for some phone calls at specific points. The writing feels plausible, with an Italian voiceover that accounts for the different mannerisms and speech patterns of the time. Most situations feel plausible and realistic, even if (probably by design) you‚Äôll end up questioning the veracity of some of them as the game progresses. Exploration & InvestigationThe story plays out through a number of days, each having a primary objective related to the events at hand, and a series of optional activities as well. Generally, you‚Äôll be able to explore the world freely at any time, with the primary areas being the villa and its courtyard, the nearby forest and the lake. Some places will be locked until specific events happen, or certain quests are triggered by your findings. Your trusty camera will be of paramount importance, as it will not only allow you to collect evidence in order to shed light on your sister‚Äôs death, but also to use filters (such as infrared) to reveal the unseen. There are a vast number of interactable objects that reveal more about the family‚Äôs past, the general lore or the people related to you in some way, each of them is voice-narrated by Giulia. Those looking to do everything will find much information in these optional interactions, they‚Äôre definitely worth the extra time spent.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2831372692Secondary QuestsWhile your focus remains finding the truth about Martha‚Äôs death, there will be other things to do as well. For instance, hidden riddles can be found by photographing specific objects in the world, optional points of interest that reveal dark stories, or trigger quests altogether. These missions may be optional, but contain a good chunk of unique content, such as puzzles, minigames and sub-storylines regarding parallel ongoing events. Some of these elements also can be missed, since the game progresses in a series of days alongside the main quest‚Äôs evolution: after certain events unfold, some areas may not be accessible anymore, thus locking the quests out forever (unless you reload an earlier save). Going just for the main story is something I wouldn‚Äôt recommend, as these secondary missions, even if a tad annoying in pacing at times, prove overall interesting and expand on the narrative considerablyPuzzles & MinigamesThe most frequent type of puzzle will be associated with photography: relevant items to frame, both primary and secondary, will be highlighted on your HUD, and it will be up to you to use the right camera accessories, such as filters, and set the right zoom level, exposure and focus to get the perfect shot. Not only that, but photos also need to be developed in a dark room, which involves a simple button-pressing prompt as QTE. Other than that, you‚Äôll eventually be decoding telegraph ciphers, finding items such as keys to unlock doors, boxes and passages containing critical items, or figure out the right things to say in a phone call to extract information. There are also a few quick-time events here and there, but they‚Äôre fairly simple and not demanding in skill or reflexes at all, in line with the genre‚Äôs expectations.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2830781865

Ultimately DOLMEN feels generic, uninspired, simplistic and devoid of any polishing despite some genuinely interesting ideas. Genre veterans may have some fun with it, but it‚Äôs objectively not a good title.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2828724614In-DepthPremise, Setting & WritingRevion Prime was just another anonymous planet under Zoan control (your faction, by the way), until the powerful DOLMEN Crystals were discovered on it. Some scientists got their hands full, started experimenting with trans-dimensional technology, and made a real mess of things - on top of other factions wanting a slice of the cake. Guess who has to clean up the mess?If the classic trope of ‚Äúsomeone fiddled with stuff they couldn‚Äôt comprehend and screwed up reality‚Äù sounds clich√®, that‚Äôs because it is. Despite locales actually feeling diverse and reasonably well-designed, at no point the narrative premise evolves past ‚Äúbash everyone in your way to get the damn crystals‚Äù or has any memorable character. We have the power-tripped supervillain, the zero-charm protagonist that says probably five lines in the entire game, the generic utilitarian radio operator, and a slew of NPCs with the personality of a rusted wheelbarrow, that have no quests or backstories whatsoever. Not even the optional lore files salvage it, as they never really prove interesting.ExplorationDOLMEN plays out as a classic souls-like in this part, meaning you‚Äôll be roaming various locales crawling with enemies, look out for the occasional item to collect, and most importantly activate Beacons (bonfires), which allow you to restore HP and Batteries (Estus), but also respawn enemies. Beacons also allow you to fast-travel between each, and teleport to your ship which contains crafting, cosmetic and leveling-up facilities, plus a totally useless NPC that just stands there staring at you menacingly.Don‚Äôt expect a complex level layout with exciting secrets and mind-bending verticality or hidden shortcuts: most levels are linear, with just a couple exceptions - most don‚Äôt even have any real shortcut or looping design at all. The only reasons to explore are crates with crafting materials, hidden NPCs that grant unique parts and lore files, but that‚Äôs all rather easy to find.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2828761665Combat System & BossesBread and butter of the experience, the combat here has some good ideas, admittedly. First of all, healing doesn‚Äôt work as you may be accustomed to for this genre. Energy (as in, Mana) acts as your healing medium, and can only be recharged with Batteries, coming in limited amounts and restored at Beacons - Estus Flask with extra steps. Mana also is used for Energy Mode, which is an amped-up status you can trigger at any time, that gives elemental powers to your attacks, other than also for ranged weapons and eventual weapon-specific abilities.The way elemental effects are handled is pretty good, as when enemies with one of the three status effects (Frozen, Burning, Poisoned) are hit with a weapon of that same element, this triggers powerful passive effects that deal significant amounts of damage - debuff first, hit second, that‚Äôs the way to go. This is a smart system that could have been built upon, but sadly it wasn‚Äôt so.Now onto the issues. The main issue with combat is the jank, with fiddly animations and mechanics that are about as reliable as that used car you bought last month from that shady salesman. What is customary in the genre just isn‚Äôt there: backstabs, ripostes, spells, stat-boosting consumables - all of this simply isn‚Äôt accounted for, making combat feel shallow not after long. The balance is all over the place really, with ranged easily overpowering everything else, alongside a fast melee as side to exploit elemental effects while energy recharges. Boss design feels average at best, with none of the fights really feeling epic despite their evolving movesets and sometimes considerable difficulty.Progression & CraftingEnemies and breakable elements drop crafting materials that can be used at the ship‚Äôs printer to craft progressively better weapons and armors, each with stat requirements to be used, of course. Each armor and weapon will contribute towards a certain Technology (Zoan, Driller, Revian) with passive abilities to match, think of it as a ‚Äòset bonus‚Äô of sorts. Crafted items can be further enhanced with Epic and Rare materials which give them better stats compared to the ‚Äúregular‚Äù versions. Unless you want to craft boss weapons, which require you to kill each boss three times (respawning them costs crystals with low drop rate), the rest of the materials will come along without particular grinding in general. You can use Nanites (souls) to improve your character stats permanently in the ship pod, and this works like in any other Souls game.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2828036749Multiplayer SystemYou can attempt bosses in jolly cooperation with your fellow DOLMEN players, using a beacon near each arena. The design of this is dement however, as it requires consumable, low-drop resources you can lose on death to be activated, no refunds in case you lose. Whoever thought gating multiplayer behind resource grinding was a good idea, didn‚Äôt think straight at all.

I can definitely recommend a full-price purchase.Verdict: Very GoodRating Chart HereA brilliant sci-fi sandbox puzzle that manages to create a fresh gameplay formula. It‚Äôs a pity the story can‚Äôt be up to par with the other excellent elements.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2826400797In-DepthPremise, Setting & WritingStory-wise, HSB starts off with a not-so-novel premise: humanity became a space-faring civilization de-facto controlled by megacorporations, with alliances and governments losing more control as time passes. LYNX is the biggest fish of them all, having pioneered modern space travel, thus amassing ludicrous amounts of power and resources. That‚Äôs who you‚Äôll be working for as a shipbreaker, tasked with dismantling decommissioned vessels for the recycling market. The game pushes heavily on the themes of ethical treatment of workers and sustainability of employment. Your shipbreaking career will be contourned not only by the stories of your colleagues, each shedding more light on the grim state of humanity and on LYNX‚Äôs dehumanizing practices, but also reinforced by dozens of data recordings found in derelict ships. From your cramped living quarters to the overly-lawyered contracts and documents piling up in your inbox, the corporate dystopia seems all too real.Shipbreaking OperationsMost of your time will be spent in the shipyard, pulling apart vessels large and small to net LYNX a big stack of cash, in shifts lasting 15 minutes each (you can dedicate multiple shifts to the same ship, don‚Äôt worry). Each ship is made of the most diverse materials and appliances depending on its role (cargo, scientific, military‚Ä¶) but it all boils down to one thing: sorting the right stuff into the right ‚Äòbin‚Äô (either furnace, processor or barge) with most things being color-coded on your scanner for this purpose.You‚Äôll have three tools for this job: the cutter, able to slice through low-density materials, vaporize walls, provide access to sealed compartments: your number one ally in dismantling things correctly. Then you have the ‚Äògravity gun‚Äô, able to move heavy objects for you to push into the right bin, and later on create Tethers, that essentially act as self-pulling ropes to haul ship parts too big for you to handle. The last tool are demo charges, able to cut entire ships in half in a matter of seconds, but at the cost of risking damage to sensitive equipment, explosions, fire hazards - use their power wisely, and only as last resort. The passive scanner highlights objects and sorts them by purpose and color, so that you know what‚Äôs what without too much hassle.The amount of perfection in how destruction, physics, explosive decompressions, fires are all recreated is great, even in failure there is some kind of strange pleasure, in seeing a ship blown in literally hundreds of smithereens flying everywhere, or the mess left inside after a decompression gone wrong.If this sounds simple enough, you‚Äôll quickly realize it isn‚Äôt. Accidents happen - often: from a small fire burning a couple of cargo crates to a critical reactor meltdown blowing away half a ship, everything demolished or processed incorrectly will be deducted from your already miserable pay, and also make you fail company Salvage Goals (more on them later). You‚Äôll have to learn how to properly disassemble many kinds of engines, machinery, reactors, and deal with mishaps on the fly before they become critical. There are even ships with rogue AIs on them, scrambling the internal systems randomly and making your life hell. Should you die, a heavy fine will be applied, but you‚Äôll respawn without penalties.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2826879455Progression SystemDepending on your performance in salvaging, you‚Äôll be credited Rank Points and Lynx Point Upon fulfilling salvage goals, which are milestones in correctly dismantling each ship - of course, more complex or hazardous ships will reward more of them. You may spend LPs to upgrade your initially pretty bad tools, making them more resilient, efficient, or even add new functions to them. Your passive gear can be enhanced as well, for instance sensors can be improved to detect more item types, while your suit can be reinforced to make you withstand even harsher conditions. Once in a while the story itself will go on, unlocking tutorial ships that will illustrate critical game mechanics or teach you how to use a new upgrade - but that‚Äôs not always the case: sometimes, especially later on, you‚Äôll have to figure things out on your own. Side Activities & CollectiblesThere are few things to do aside from shipbreaking, and they mostly relate to collecting. Posters found in wrecks can be taken, and used to customize your habitation pod. Stickers, awarded for progression milestones or particularly good performances, can be put onto tools as a cosmetic enhancement, but serve no other purpose. At some point a ‚Äòship repair‚Äô minigame will come up, allowing you to illegally salvage components that should go to LYNX for your own purposes. Decrypting and listening (or reading) lost data recording can be interesting, as it sheds light on the state of the galaxy, but it will take a huge amount of time to find them all.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2826400964Additional Game ModesFree Play allows you to pick from any ship models, everything unlocked, to just have some fun either scrapping it correctly or blowing it to bits - sandbox no-consequence mode. Cutter‚Äôs RACE is sort of a time trial where you can compete against the clock to salvage a ship as fast - and as well - as humanly possible.

Better in co-op.Visit our website, Indie Hive[indie-hive.com], to read other interesting reviews and articles.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2820944226In-DepthPremise, Setting & WritingAfter busting out of a cryostasis pod, you find yourself in an abandoned facility with no memories. Soon enough you find a damaged robot that explains some of the recent events, including that his friend, Dr Schip, is building a spacecraft to flee the planet and go back to the civilized systems. The hard-to-obtain materials can only be found in the bowels of the planet - that‚Äôs how your cave-crawling, pickaxe-wielding adventure begins.Something went seriously wrong - you can tell that after seeing demolished villages filled with horribly mutated people and abominations. Still, there are also normal folks around, belonging to various fantasy races like Elves, Orcs and so on. You won‚Äôt see them defending against the horrors or do anything else than going around, though. In the underground, cramped, dark tunnels filled with all kinds of dangers are the norm. The atmosphere is cartoony and works fine, but lacks boldness most of the time.The story is not elaborate, despite the good number of lore files found in dungeons and facilities as you travel. The attempt made at indirect narration, with a ‚Äúbuild-your-own-interpretation‚Äù approach works only partially, and you‚Äôll scratch your head about more than a few things. Still, it‚Äôs an ARPG, so the story was never a high expectation.Exploration, Progression & CraftingWhile the planet‚Äôs surface has a lot going on, like fast-travel portals absent underground, and NPC villages offering items for sale and unique services, most of Keplerth‚Äôs world actually expands vertically. Across five biomes, you‚Äôll progressively find better and more plentiful minerals, paired with stronger foes the deeper you get. You can go underground with stairwells that need to be of better materials to pierce the harder ground, effectively preventing you from going too deep too soon.Modifying your genome and crafting better gear are the keys to beat all the horrors waiting for you. Felling plants, digging minerals and killing enemies may drop unique ‚Äòmutated‚Äô materials that can be used, along with T-Energy, to unlock passive skills you can equip, swap anytime in the form of modules. These can be arranged in a limited space, acting as a little Tetris of sorts, and have set bonuses for further specialization. Paired with gear set bonuses or unique properties, re-rollable buffs, the possible build variety becomes quite wide. To do most of that, plenty of materials will be needed: killing enemies, breeding livestock, digging minerals will all be things you need to do, especially later on, to obtain enough rare materials to keep up with crafting requirements - don‚Äôt worry, crops and animals mostly take care of themselves once started.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2820300636Combat System & BossesThe combat is rather straightforward. It uses active skills, ranged and melee weapons as means of offense, depending on your build of choice - skills are acquired only later on from Events, and not unlocked by leveling (there‚Äôs no leveling at all, or attributes, in fact). Arguably, fights with normal enemies are one of the weakest components: despite the variety of builds, weapons and skills, most of them play out as a simple trade of blows, without dodging, blocking, parrying or any other skill-based mechanic to make the difference and offer more nuance. The same can‚Äôt be said for bosses, which keep attention high thanks to various phases, and often spam tons of adds for good measure, too. Once a boss is beaten, the next tech level will be unlocked, although all of them can respawn, and you can fight them to get rare drops from their loot pool. Just don‚Äôt attempt Tough difficulty if you go solo - really, the bosses become so spongy, lethal and self-healing, you‚Äôll have to grind the hell out of rolls, skills and companions to even make a dent in them.Base ManagementOther than storing items in chests (that can‚Äôt be labeled, which is annoying), your base will be useful for two other things: farming and being a Bed & Breakfast. Yeah that‚Äôs right: other than crops and cattle, useful to get ingredients to cook meals, but also gene-altering ingredients and crafting materials, you can also recover people in distress. They‚Äôll live in your base, use the facilities you make for them, and pay you a literal rent. They won‚Äôt defend it, obey your commands, and just eat, sleep and bathe in saunas all the time. But those bucks are great, in fact citizens are the best source of income long-term.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2821119940Invasions & EventsIf you enable them, Invasions will happen regularly based on the highest depth you reach. Enemies will build outposts near your base, then attack you periodically, until you manage to demolish their base - they will try to break down doors, enter and make a mess of things, so fending them off becomes a regular nuisance, that however awards materials and items. Event Portals are found a few biomes in, they award currency bundles, unique skills or rare pets with often strong passives - definitely worth it. Random spawns like abandoned facilities, cities and other areas may also happen, often they have their own kinds of enemies and rewards to match, adding more to the exploration part.

Yet, it‚Äôs held back by poor translation, technical shenanigans and some less-than-ideal design choices.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2819164034In-DepthPremise, Setting & WritingThe incipit of MMXR is hardly novel: mankind created an AI to solve the crippling environmental issues of our planet. It worked quite too well, as it (rightly) concluded humans were the primary issue. In the consequent dystopian world you‚Äôll wear the boots of Talis, one of the few surviving humans, hell-bent on destroying all the machines.Set in the aptly-named Dystokio, MMXR introduces you to a deserted world nearly-devoid of life, save for mutant abominations. The few remaining humans reside at Iron Base, Talis and crew‚Äôs main operations center. Between sandy expanses and crumbling bunkers, the post-apo feel is definitely there, but don‚Äôt expect an overly-realistic take on it. It‚Äôs sad that the visuals aren‚Äôt up-to-par with 2022 standards: at times it looks like a PS2 game!The side-characters aiding Talis‚Äô endeavor will have distinct personalities, however don‚Äôt expect much elaboration on their backstories, nor great changes of character from them at any point - they‚Äôre sufficient sidekicks, nothing more. The lore itself is quite good, however the terrible translation often butchers it, rendering it less enjoyable.ExplorationIs mainly performed using a variety of tanks and armored vehicles, however there are a good amount of sections where you‚Äôll be forced to go on foot, as well. Dystokio is divided into five large sectors that you‚Äôll progressively access as the story goes on - while the game promotes ‚Äúnon-linear open world‚Äù, this isn‚Äôt true since going too far will get you steamrolled by overpowered foes. Your minimap indicates all loot-crates, digging spots and respawning resource piles, so there won‚Äôt be any eye-squinting in the search for loot, which of course becomes better as areas become more advanced. Teleporting back to base and back again is something doable at any time, except during combat; a convenient feature that merges with Fast Travel Points, that act as ‚Äòcheckpoints‚Äô of sorts across the five zones. Each square meter is littered with respawning enemies that will attack should you stay in their vision cone long enough - not immediately, so there‚Äôs some time to avoid trash encounters if you want.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2819163981Combat SystemIs divided between ‚Äòon foot‚Äô and ‚Äòon vehicles‚Äô, both of them using a turn-based mode with an optional auto-attack function that effectively makes it real-time until toggled. In the former, you‚Äôll use Talis plus two sidekicks, and fight across tunnels, buildings, crevasses and whatever place is too narrow to reach by tank. Characters can be equipped with a variety of weapons, melee and ranged, with diverse firing patterns, ranges, AoEs and damage types. This becomes important later on, when many enemies will have specific resistances or weaknesses. Fights are your standard JRPG affair, with turns where you can use items, skills or simply attack. As XP is gathered (only for active party members), you‚Äôll be able to spend Skill Points in one of the six specialization trees, each granting special passive and active abilities.Vehicle combat works in the same way, but with a twist: each tank has Armor instead of HP and won‚Äôt be destroyed when that reaches zero, instead Components (engine, cannons, etc.) will start taking damage, eventually disabling the tank completely and forcing the driver to fight on foot (usually a deadly proposition against vehicle-grade foes). Of course going back to base will repair everything, but also field fixing is possible, albeit in a slow way, since each item has a lengthy usage animation. Tanks will progressively become unrealistic, hulking monstrosities with five cannons, somehow operated by a single crewman; up to three can be brought with you on any sortie. Fighting on paper is complex, with many status effects, skills, passives and damage types - while these factors have to be accounted in the harder fights, most of the time simply building your tank platoon properly and setting auto-attack on will clear most scuffles without a hitch.Customization & ProgressionIron Base allows you to craft, improve and purchase a vast array of components and weapons for your crew and vehicles. Better engines will increase your tanks‚Äô maximum weight limit, allowing them to carry heavier, better weaponry and armor without incurring in the heavy HP maluses derived from overweight. There‚Äôs no equipment limit, money does all the talking in MMXR and acts sort of like a ‚Äòsecond XP‚Äô: get rich enough via selling, missions and enemy killing (bounties especially), and you‚Äôll quickly get your hands on powerful gear. Individual weapons can as well be modified into 2.0 and 3.0 variants with the right materials, lightened or hardened to be more resilient in exchange for more weight cost, the latter also goes for vehicles. Chips unlock powerful abilities, like attacking with all cannons at the same time instead of one at a time, or perform other special moves, but they‚Äôre expensive and need to be installed with a specific strategy in mind, to obtain the best synergy, stack effects.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2819164116

It lacks polishing, and is lackluster in some aspects, sure, but not too bad overall for Indie standards.Visit our website, Indie Hive[indie-hive.com], to read other interesting reviews and articles.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2815616728In-DepthPremise, Setting & WritingAfter the Great Migration, most of humanity moved to a large continent known only as ‚ÄúThe West‚Äù, currently under the control of three major factions, hanging in a fragile peace brokered after several bloody conflicts. You‚Äôll play as grizzled war veteran Jeb Rockwell, a no-nonsense hardcore cowboy with a small but skilled crew under his command. Soon enough, a certain event triggers newfound lust for vengeance in Jeb, as he chooses to embark on a journey filled with political intrigue, secrecy and - of course - a good dose of violence.The blend of steampunk and western settings is hardly innovative, however AoG manages to do it right thanks to a solid amount of lore not only about the main cast and events, but also technology, society, history and other aspects - most of which is gained through optional dialogues. Generally, characters and quests have solid writing, with a high amount of exposure and details that contribute in painting a clearer picture of what‚Äôs going on, even if at times some aspects may seem implausible or irrational. Exploration & Side ActivitiesDue to finite fuel, your ship will be limited to predetermined routes along the world map, with cities and outposts being ‚Äòdots‚Äô along these imaginary roads - there‚Äôs no free-roaming (which is disappointing for an RPG), but there may be random events along the way, such as enemy encounters or discoveries with positive or negative outcomes. Each location can be entered, displaying important characters to speak with, which in turn may give information, assign quests, have stuff to trade, or even challenge Jeb to a duel. Cities serve as ‚Äòhubs‚Äô for character dialogues, essentially, and it‚Äôs important to note some of them may evolve or not be available anymore, as days dynamically pass while traveling. The main side-activity will be questing (usually assassination or fetch assignments), of course, although trading comes as a close second: buying low to sell high where a specific good is in higher demand can net good profits, too bad your cargo hold can never be upgraded in size, so this is a relatively low risk but tedious way of making money.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2815616582Combat SystemAlways one-on-one and with simultaneous turns, combat pits ships against each other in aerial duels. Each turn you‚Äôll be able to choose where to spend your steam points (no pun intended‚Ä¶): activate your radar for passive bonuses in evasion, armor penetration and accuracy, rev up the engine to gain more steam next turn (but watch out for overheating), or use it on weapons, enabling them to fire more powerful volleys the more steam is used to juice them up. Most murder tools have special random effects that may influence your or the enemy‚Äôs ship, such as setting them on fire, blowing up in your face, or disabling a system, other than their own accuracy rating, steam cost per shot, penetration values. It may seem like a lot of factors to consider, but at the end of the day the best strategy is buffing up, stacking steam for some turns, then unleashing all your weapons on whatever poor sod you‚Äôre fighting, usually obliterating them.You get a chance to get some of  your foes‚Äô weapons or gear when you kill them, to then use them or sell them at a city for an extra buck. Combat has a decent system but a lot of features feel under-utilized, it‚Äôs not as complex as it seems really, despite the game kinda ‚Äòwanting‚Äô it to be. It doesn‚Äôt help that enemy AI isn‚Äôt exactly the brightest.Progression SystemYour ship‚Äôs gear and weapons represent the only progression you‚Äôll get - there are no skill trees, no passive / active abilities, no traits (that‚Äôs why I said the RPG component is lackluster!). As you plow through bandits, military and complete quests, you‚Äôll be able to buy or find better hulls, components, guns and so forth - making you able to withstand more punishment and deal with stronger foes - which does feel rewarding. It‚Äôs straightforward, with no limitations as to what you may or may not equip, as long as you have the space for it - no stat requirements or anything such.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2815616470Dialogues & Roleplaying ComponentWhile dialogues are extensive and rather elaborate (despite mostly linear), the same can‚Äôt be said about the actual roleplaying. Jeb may choose to deal with situations in one way or another, sure, such as by sparing or killing a character, or solving problems in a more diplomatic manner (often resulting in Karma Tokens being earned), opposite to Infamy Tokens, awarded for actions considered ‚Äòevil‚Äô. The metric upon which this is determined is not always the best, as a few times a clearly good action awarded Infamy, and vice-versa, for apparently no reason.What hurts more, perhaps AoG‚Äôs worst problem, is that no matter how famous (or infamous) you become, people will react to you in the same way regardless, this won‚Äôt bar you from any quest or anything else - as it often is the case in RPG sporting a morality system. The dialogue choices often lead to the same conclusion, and give only a fake sense of choice that isn't really there.

Sum-UpIn-depth analysis further down.üü© Prosüü• Cons- The good variety of situations throughout the campaign contributes in keeping interest relatively high.- All weapons feel diverse, fun to use and prove useful against specific types of enemies or situations.- Interesting premise and setting, that however aren‚Äôt elaborated upon enough.- Reasonably satisfying challenge level on ‚ÄòHard‚Äô difficulty.- Generic clich√®d story, dull protagonist and forgettable side characters that don‚Äôt hook the player at any point. - Heavily recycled locations through both main and side activities.- Badly-designed backtracking system, that makes collectibles and hidden secondary activities a mind-numbing chore.- Inconsistent graphics put visually-appealing models and textures alongside extremely low-quality ones.- Horrendous control system on Mouse & Keyboard (‚ÄòP‚Äô to pick up items? Seriously?!).- Multiplayer is dead: I was unable to try it.üü® Bugs & Issuesüîß Specs- Key rebinding doesn‚Äôt work properly and glitches the controls.- FMV cutscenes are compressed to extremely low quality.- Missing or wrong button prompts while performing specific actions.- Alt-tabbing may cause freezes or crashes.- 3900X- 2080Ti- 32GB RAM- SSD- 1440pContent & Replay Value:It took me around 16 hours to complete Lost Planet 3 (LP3) on Hard difficulty, while also doing a good number of side-activities (though not all). Given the linear nature of all activities, I see no reason to replay once completed.Is it worth buying?No. This game is nearly ten years old, and only offers mediocre quality; the price of 25‚Ç¨ is totally unwarranted as it is now. You might want to pick it up just to finish the franchise if you‚Äôre a fan, on sale (as I did), but generally I‚Äôd recommend avoiding it completely to most people.Verdict: MediocreRating Chart HereLP3 is a disappointing conclusion to an already less-than-stellar franchise. Evident porting issues, clich√®d story and cheap asset recycling make this one more of a slog than anything else, its redeeming qualities just too weak to drag it out of the pits.Follow our Curator page, Summit Reviews, to see more high-quality reviews regularly.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2813764042In-DepthPremise, Setting & WritingIn a rather plausible future, Earth has acquired interplanetary capabilities, however it also incurred a massive energy crisis as its resources came on the verge of depletion. The solution? T-Energy, a near-miraculous, all-purpose power source found in the bowels of a remote ice ball known as EDN 3. You‚Äôll wear the insulated boots of Jim Payton, an external contractor working for interplanetary megacorp NEVEC, and tasked with acquiring as much of the substance as possible, while fighting against both extreme conditions and the dangerous local fauna.LP3‚Äôs setting is realized rather well, as it manages to convey great desolation and sense of loss with the stalagmite-ridden, storm-ravaged areas of the planet. The struggle of NEVEC‚Äôs teams against nearly-untameable forces of nature and the deadly Akrid is portrayed well, as it is the profit-oriented corporate mindset that prevails above all else. At times, mostly through rundown facilities and damp caves, LP3 also deviates to a more ‚Äòhorror-like‚Äô atmosphere and does so decently well.Despite such potential and premise, all the characters that encompass Jim‚Äôs adventures, up to and including himself, prove unremarkable. An insipid protagonist is put side-by-side with ‚Äòtextbook antagonistic underdog‚Äô, cheerful ‚Äònotice me senpai‚Äô youngster trying to shine, ‚Äòtired boss‚Äô and more clich√®d characters from start to end. The story is rarely interesting, as it uses the already tired ‚Äòhumans shouldn‚Äôt meddle with what they don‚Äôt understand‚Äô trope to produce a mediocre plot that feels stale, already-seen after just a couple hours.General GameplayBeing a corporate contractor, your job will be executing various tasks from your superiors, which act as main missions. Your faithful RIG - an industrial bipedal robot as tall as a house - will be a vital asset to accomplish the job, as it‚Äôs equipped with utility tools that double as weapons. LP3 alternates RIG-driving phases with much more common on-foot sections, where the careful explorers will be rewarded, as there‚Äôre T-energy (currency) drops hidden around, lore-related material and Specialized Components, vital to upgrade your RIG with new, better functions.While the main activity is fighting Akrid hordes, there‚Äôs a bit of simple platforming, some puzzle-solving and exploring thrown in the mix, to give some much-needed variety to the loop. While this is an appreciable effort, the extremely limited roster of locations will weigh down heavily as you pass the same place, with the same enemies, for the 5th time in a row to do some side-quest. Generally you‚Äôll unlock more weapons, upgrades and RIG enhancements as the main story progresses, although some of these are tied to secondary quests or even collectible-fetching.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2813763927Combat SystemJim will carry two primary weapons with limited ammo, and the classic ‚Äòinfinite pistol‚Äô as sidearm, plus a couple very powerful grenades. Almost anywhere, EDN 3 is crawling with Akrid of diverse shapes and sizes - each with different abilities and attack patterns. All weapons have some sort of specialty target, for instance the sniper rifle will be great against single, armored targets but near useless versus hordes - special ammo that drastically alters how each gun functions is a thing, too, but can‚Äôt be refilled by normal ammo drops to offset its power. Generally, fighting Akrid involves well-timed dodges, taking cover from ranged attacks, and hitting the glowing weak spots to inflict major damage, although some fights (especially bosses) may have unique mechanics unto themselves, that however rarely prove truly exciting or fresh - actually, they mostly prove clunky, half-assed garbage.RIG combat sees Jim using his mech to deal punishment to the enemies, despite it not being a military vehicle. A 10-ton drill to the head will instantly kill most smaller enemies, and deal massive damage to larger ones - given that their weak spots are exposed. A system of quick-time prompts to trigger counter-attacks and special moves exists when fighting most ‚Äòbig guys‚Äô, however I found that using the RIG is generally a downgrade compared to going down and dealing with them on foot as your weapons, united with Jim‚Äôs agility, are just better than the RIG‚Äôs.Character Progression & Side ContentUsing the T-energy awarded from missions and kills, Jim will not only be able to upgrade his tools, but also acquire new ones alongside unique upgrades tied to the completion of specific side-quests. While the character doesn‚Äôt directly evolve, his equipment will. For instance, finding the rare Albino Tarkaas specimen will enable purchasing permanent passive skills, while extracting samples for the base‚Äôs chief scientist will unlock special ammo. These side-missions, while sometimes worthy in terms of rewards, prove extremely boring, slow and dull due to the overall pacing riddled with transitions, loading times and useless waiting: trust me, you will get bored of such chores long before the end of it all.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2813840508

First release in 2020 for the PS4. Reinterpretation of the PS1 classic that only shows the first 8-hours of Final Fantasy VII and stretch into a 33-hours game. The real problem is that they made structure and story changes that destroyed the magic of the original. If you haven't played FFVII before, I recommend the 1997 version first. Note: The review is based on my Final Fantasy VII Remake playthrough on PS4 and a replay the the original FFVII (PS4 port - Midgar Part) in 2020. ‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†ÄMy curator page‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä

Another FromSoftware masterpiece which takes the ‚ÄûDark Souls DNA‚Äú and put it into an Action-adventure game.Positive(1) Great soundtrack especially at bossfights(2) Fast loading times(3) HDR support(4) Great visuals(5) Fixed difficulty setting (6) Very demanding Bossfights but never unfair (7) Native Xbox One Controller support. DUALSHOCK 4 also supported(8) Good enemy placement(9) Perfectly balanced progression system so you can't be overpowered(10) Superb fast combat and satisfying parry mechanic(11) Good level design but doesn't come up to the class of Dark Souls 1(12) Replayability because of New Game+ and different endings (new bosses)Negative(1) 60 fps lock(2) No ultrawide native support (only via mods)(3) Only one default main weapon and armorMY REVIEW SETUP:

First released in 1995 for the SNES and designed by the "Dream Team" Hironobu Sakaguchi (creator of Square's Final Fantasy series), Yuji  Horii (creator of Enix's Dragon Quest series) and Akira  Toriyama (creator of the Dragonball mangas). The Steam version is based on the mobile port. I played it for the first time in 2018 and it's amazing how well this game has aged. For me its: Still one of the best JRPG ever made.Positive Straight forward time travel story with great pacing and no filler Replayability because of different endings Active Time Battle (ATM) System with NO separate fighting screen and random encounters Superb soundtrack (composed by Yasunori Mitsuda and Nobuo Uematsu) Original graphic mode: "Similar to the original pixel art"  Fixed difficulty setting Native 16:9 support 4:3 support, to play it in fullscreen you have to change the system resolution to 4:3 Native Xbox One Controller support. DUALSHOCK 4 also supported Negative Modified mobile User Interface. No original SNES UI Partly custom controller binding. You could only change X, Y, B and A buttons The onscreen conroller buttons only shows the Xbox layout MY REVIEW SETUP: i7-6700K | 32 GB DDR4 | GTX 1080 FE | HDD install | Win 10 Pro |

This is a very unique game with lots of features such as picking up items, climbing walls and the ability to change character at any time. The main character is a little girl named "Mary" and she fell asleep in a wardrobe after hiding from her parents arguing and now when she wakes up she discorvers that she is in an magical world full of giant strawberries and magical druids!. She has a friend called "Aquarius" and togheter they walk around in this world solving puzzles and quests trying to find a way back to the real world. It got great graphics.Pros:The game is cheap and you can get trading cards. The graphics are amazing The music is greatThe physics are 10/10The controls are easy to get used toCons: There is no menu or tutorial

What an awesome new way to experience Portal!Playing with the element of time, where what you do in the past affect the future, but what you do in the future does not affect the past. Kinda obvious but spooky when put into practical use.The levels could be very challenging if the concept isn't entirely understood, which makes it all the more fun and exciting to solve.I hope for new levels and more content like this!Community content taken to an official level, awesome stuff!

It was not mentioned that co-op is only with random people.Can't get a refund as I waited over 2 weeks to play with a friend.The game itself is amazing and I was very hyped towards the experience, but this weird decision to make it co-op only with strangers - makes it more a singleplayer game than an "online co-op" game.

I have no idea how, but it's even better than DOOM 2016.Epic carnage, blood, gore, weapons. Fast paced action all around.Story really gives you a reason to want to push through the hordes and move forward.A bunch of collectables with a great map that helps finding the general direction of the hidden item, but still leaving the search to the player.Saving is very limited, very specific auto-save checkpoints and end of missions.Forced me to leave the game open when I had to leave yet didn't want to lose progress.But whatever.All around a great experience, worth my money.

Very challenging but with the dedication that is required comes great satisfaction and fun.Dark Souls in Japanese, Katanas, Kiminos and other elements that indicate Asian culture.I loved the challenge and the thrill of facing an impossible boss again, and again, and again; and finally becoming so good you destroy that boss in a great attempt.Spent my weekends playing this while off the army, enjoyed the struggle and travel around the game.
Great fun, satisfying and fun with friends. Could be challenging at times, but youtube is always there to help you out. Great price. No regret in playing a mobile game on my GTX1080ti.

It might be short, but size doesn't matter. (Right?)An amazing experience, just diving into this world and exploring it, the way everything's done, satisfying, high quality.I'm not a game reviewer but I definitely should've played this earlier.What an amazing ride.

What an interesting experience!I very much enjoyed the beautiful sountrack the game has, the pixel art is simplistic and beatifully done!The actions you do and the way the world responds to you is often satisfying, ecouraging you to not procrastinate!The gameplay is simple: Build smart enough to protect what makes you coins so that you may either conquer the land and leave to the next or just leave to the next one. That's my way of seeing it ignoring the road getting to your purpose.The challenge of the game for me is in two things:1. Earning coins: It's not simple to establish a good source of coins, as you get attacked and caught off guard at times which destroys all your work, and rebuilding deep into the game is suicide as you will encounter more enemies as the days go by.2. NPC speed: The builders you hire and command, the beggers you give coin and reason to walk to your town, all WALK so SLOWLY!!! I can't count the amount of times I saw a begger I payed die because he walked so slowly towards the town.DAYS will pass by the time far away builders will finally come to your position and get what you need done. Of course they can die easily if you didn't plan ahead their position when the enemy's horde pummels through your walls.These 2 incredible challenges made me too frustrated to continue playing normally, so I get a Cheat Engie table for some "boosters" as god mode, infinitie coins, archers that shoot more arrows a second than there are trees in the entire game, and so on.To summerize:The game is made beautifully made and is challenging!So prepare yourself for some tough times, but maybe you'll like the struggle. The beautiful sountrack and design will help you through it all, so have at it at your own risk.The price is fair, so don't wait for a sale and support these great developers!

‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• what a ride!You might think that 13 hours is little, but every ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• minute was fun.(I only finished the story, got lots of fun maps to explore with my friends!)Gameplay wise, it's too much fun.The variety of weapons and their uses, their mods and upgrades, makes it all awesome fun.Lots of blood and crazy animations. Movement is pretty simple for the most of it.The powerups that you can find are ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• AWESOME!The maps are full of interesting things to find and explore, adding more to the killings you do endlessly.Story wise, it's pretty good.While it's not Witcher 3-36-possible-endings-GOTY-tear-spawning-heart-crushing-love-making story,It's good enough to give you purpose and some things to think about. The characters are interesting and each with their own ideas and ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• whatever I like killing stuff.Personally it felt a bit slow at the start, but it was probably just to get new players used to the game.To summerize,It's an experience every gamer who thinks he likes FPS should try,an experience every gamer who thinks he likes to kill should try,an experience every gamer who thinks he like to have fun should try.Truely, a masterpiece.TL;DRSTOP WASTING YOUR TIME READING THIS AND ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• BUY IT IT'S ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• AWESOME

I'll never be able to describe the experience as a whole in words, the story and gameplay is just too much.The DLCs are amazing, price feels just right for the amount of content they add.I find this a very enjoyable game, beatifully made and written.Fighting is interesting although simple, the riddles are too much fun to solve,roaming the beautiful maps is amazing, listening to the music is exciting,and finishing the game is heartbreaking..I wish I had a meme or something to finish the review, but this game is worthy of much than that.I leave my heart here. The feelings the game awoke in me reside in this review.Feast on them, and know what a real game can make you feel.

Awesome gameplay, a damn shame it's peer2peer connection, dedicated servers would've made this a 5/5 trumps.I gives this 3 trumps out of five, damn connection is annoying when people are continents away from you.

This game is NOT an RPG despite steam tags, it is visual novel/adventure and as a visual novel it is really one of the best in this genre. But I like RPG games and don't really like visual novel genre so should i recommend it? I will, yes, because the writing is really good, stories, music and climat are good and enjoyable but gameplay which is usually the most important thing for me isn't really convincing, it is too basic, there are no real rpg elements, adventure yes, you will immerse some good written stories and you have some decision which will change what outcome, mostly cards you get but thats it. Also minus from technical side, videos are not working for me, I must skip them (my graphic card rtx 2060). Overall game is not terrible, it is good in its department and unique, can be fun, you can enjoy it, so I recommend. PS - I got more interested in this game because of tv series Carnivale (same times and location) which i really liked ;-)
Very good story and soundtrack. A few different endings. Enjoyed the game.
A new better version of the best fantasy strategy game, continuously updated and extended. You will like it single player too. Mass of content.

It is a good game, an original concept (like in many Arcen companygames) and this is always very welcomed by me after playing numerous other similiar genre/climat games. You need to plan your strategy, in main game mode diplomacy is a key as you must help all (independent) space races to unite in alliance, all races are really much different so it is interesting goal, you are like a third side here and this is also unique. Events are there both random and planned by other races and you, everything is designed with some deep. Game looks very good, it has definitely very good music (really not expected this), everything is running very smooth. Often you need to take part in many quite similiar fight (like when fighting insurgents) which could be a "con" but they are very quick, enough so it is not bad. I can recommend. ps - Next time i will try on higher difficulties, espec. space fights seemed too easy to manage on my "normal" first playthrough.
The best game tagged as "casual" I ever played :)

Interesting multiplayer game, good gameplay but still many changes in early access, hard to tell how the game will finish.+ Different gameplay for both main classes and for sub-classes both of hunters and scavangers. Fun shooting and hunting experience for Hunter and co-operation, stealth playing of Scavangers, many different perks and powers making game more complex.- It still is much visible it is early access, dev are doing very big gameplay, mechanics and balance changes in patches like those last one and there are no info ingame about changes, after patches custom controls need to be set again and there are no infos about all actions possible with those keys in game especially for those newly created/changed mechanics, of course it can be all explained by early access.- No bots, if final product will not have them longivity of the game may be much shortened, also options of mixing players/bots could be good for a faster match starts/queues. In general i feel fps multiplayer games need to have bots for game to not risk dying too early.
Great climate and gameplay, mechanics even improved since Dishonored 1. Good locations, big fun to play.

+ Great depth of gameplay+ Another part of fantastic and the best football manager series+ For all fans of football and for all fans of tactics+ Good as always database+ Developing young players even better then before (09)+ Great simulation and strategy+- Extremely time consuming, good dedicated managers should get paid in real money for playing this lol :x- Some bugs from earlier versions still not fixed, like those with players registration to Club World Champ.- Some qualifing rules to club international cups are not described enought ingame like those in Mexican league. Well i could find many minor bugs but they are maybe not so important for overall review.

Eng: One of the best games ever, massive content and lore, planning and diversity, immersive climat, beside battle formations turn based queued orders planned before, very detailed amazing very deep fantasy strategy.ps - don't suggest my game hours, I played it without steam overlay. Edit: Updated with even more added content (free ofc) and factions and many other things as every version for very long time, now new version is coming (5) but it doesn't change much, it is a perfect game. Pl: Jedna z najlepszych gier w historii, rewelacyjna gra strategiczna, gleboka, ogromna zawartosc z rownie ogromnym lore.

Cependant, si vous vous lancez dans l'aventure principalement pour le c√¥t√© joueur contre joueur du titre, une seconde d√©ception vous attend.D'une part, nous avons le PvP sauvage. Vous pouvez activer/d√©sactiver le mode PvP lorsque vous √™tes en ville, pour ensuite partir √† la chasse aux joueurs. Vous r√©aliserez alors que la seule fa√ßon de "profiter" du PvP sauvage, c'est de vous aussi rejoindre un √©norme groupe pour rouler sur les malheureux quoi croiseront votre route.C'est aussi la seule fa√ßon pour une faction de d√©clarer la guerre √† un territoire : faire un bus, prendre les qu√™tes PvP, suivre le m√™me chemin boucle apr√®s boucle pendant une heure afin de remplir la jauge d'attaque, jusqu'√† pouvoir d√©clarer la guerre. M√™me si les factions adverses feront de m√™me pour vous contrer, la faction dominante sur le territoire ne pourra pas vraiment d√©fendre, tant leur influence sur la barre d'attaque sera r√©duite.Arrive alors la guerre : un joyeux bordel √† 50 contre 50. Malheureusement, les serveurs ne tiennent pas la route, et le lag vous emp√™chera de combattre convenablement. Proposer de si grandes batailles sans pouvoir assurer que √ßa fonctionne bien, c'est quand m√™me con. De plus, ces derni√®res sont √©litistes : la guilde qui poss√®de le territoire choisira ses combattants. En clair, si vous n'√™tes pas au niveau maximum, ou si quelqu'un ne vous aime pas, vous ne combattrez jamais.De plus, le jeu se voulant facilement abordable comme je l'expliquais plus haut, cela fait que le PvP n'est pas profond, et m√™me plut√¥t limit√©.Il reste heureusement la d√©ferlante, qui est un mode de jeu domination en 20 contre 20, sans distinction de faction, et qui se r√©v√®le plut√¥t sympathique.L'aspect PvE est lui plus r√©ussi. Atteindre le niveau maximum (qui est 60) se fait facilement car chaque action donne de l'exp√©rience, et obtenir un √©quipement haut niveau n'est pas bien dur. Vous tournerez donc vite en rond, car ce ne sont pas les quelques donjons que le jeu propose qui vous permettront une certaine rejouabilit√©, ni les diff√©rentes qu√™tes du jeu.Il reste les invasions, qui sont l'√©quivalent des guerres mais en PvE. Cette fois, la s√©lection des joueurs se fera diff√©remment. La guilde qui contr√¥le le territoire attaqu√© ne pourra choisir que 10 joueurs, les 40 autres seront d√©termin√©s al√©atoirement. Si cela permettait aux gens de pouvoir avoir une chance de participer √† du contenu haut niveau, ce n'est en fait pas si s√ªr, car durant les quinze minutes de pr√©paration pr√©c√©dant l'invasion, la guilde qui contr√¥le pourra exclure des joueurs, en esp√©rant qu'un autre plus "int√©ressant" soit s√©lectionn√©. En gros, ils peuvent faire en sorte de faire passer les copains.Le fait que des territoires puissent √™tre contr√¥l√©s directement par les joueurs offre une m√©canique int√©ressante au jeu, la gestion de l'√©conomie. Lorsque vous mettez des objets en vente √† l'h√¥tel des ventes, que vous fabriquerez des objets ou si vous poss√©dez une maison, diverses taxes appliqu√©es par la guilde qui contr√¥le la zone s'appliqueront. L'argent r√©col√© par les taxes servira ensuite √† am√©liorer la ville pour permettre aux joueurs d'avoir acc√®s √† des objets de plus haut niveau pour leur m√©tier, mais aussi pour la d√©fense de la ville lors des guerres et des invasions. Il est dommage que ce point puisse √™tre ruin√© par la communaut√©, j'y viendrais ensuite.Qui dit MMO, dit farming. Comme New World permet √† ses joueurs d'utiliser l'int√©gralit√© de tous les m√©tiers que le jeu propose, vous vous doutez que vous allez passer pas mal de temps √† cueillir, couper du bois, fabriquer des armes et j'en passe. Force est d'admettre que le farm dans New World est bien amen√©. Les ressources relient les m√©tiers entre eux, rendant la chose plus sympathique √† d√©couvrir et √† faire.Maintenant je vais aborder les deux points les plus n√©gatifs du jeu. Premi√®rement, les bugs. Il y en a √©norm√©ment, et ces derniers ont un impact fort et n√©gatif sur des aspects importants du titre comme le PvP ou l'√©conomie. Par exemple, √† l'heure o√π j'√©cris ces lignes il existe un bug qui permet √† la faction attaquante de gagner une guerre en seulement quelques minutes. Un autre a fait que les joueurs pouvaient dupliquer des objets et de l'argent, obligeant l'√©quipe de d√©veloppement √† bloquer l'h√¥tel des ventes et les √©changes. Des bugs concernant aussi les armes, rendant certaines totalement inefficaces en combat, alors que d'autres sont devenues extr√™mement mortelles.Deuxi√®mement, sa communaut√©. C'est lorsque l'on joue √† New World que l'on se dit qu'un MMO qui demande un abonnement mensuel, ce n'est pas forc√©ment une mauvaise chose. Cela permet de faire un tri, et d'√©viter d'avoir une communaut√© enti√®rement toxique.Car malheureusement, celle de New World est un cancer en phase terminale. Les canaux de discussions sont infest√©s de trolls, les insultes y fusent sans arr√™t, tout comme le trashtalk et les d√©bats idiots montrant toute absence intellectuelle chez certains. Si vous vous lancez dans le jeu, un conseil : masquez le tchat.Mais les choses ne s'arr√™tent malheureusement pas aux seules discussions. Comme New World propose un gameplay qui donne du pouvoir aux joueurs, vous allez avoir √† faire aux pires comportements possibles en jeu. Vous vous doutez que l'exploitation des bugs se fait √† outrance, les guildes qui ont du pouvoir n'h√©sitent parfois pas √† en abuser, celles qui n'ont pas de pouvoir n'h√©sitent parfois pas √† saboter la d√©fense des autres (alors qu'elles combattent pour la m√™me faction.). Il est aussi courant que le chef d'une guilde qui poss√®de un ou plusieurs territoires vole l'argent g√©n√©r√© par les taxes avant de fuir en d√©truisant la guilde, laissant un ou des territoires sans contr√¥le, cela ayant un impact n√©gatif sur l'influence de la faction et l'√©conomie.Bon, terminons au moins sur une note positive : l'OST du jeu est superbe. Malgr√© tout, je recommande ce jeu, car il reste possible de s'amuser entre amis, et si vous ne jouez pas avec de grosses attentes.Retrouvez mes critiques sur SensCritique ![www.senscritique.com]

Retrouvez toutes mes critiques sur SensCritique ![www.senscritique.com]Si vous jouez √† Deadlight uniquement pour sa trame sc√©naristique, vous faites erreur. Non pas parce qu'elle est mauvaise. M√™me si elle est agr√©able √† suivre, en grande partie gr√¢ce √† la belle direction artistique du jeu, elle reste pr√©visible et peu originale.Si un jeu comme Limbo a pu vous plaire, Deadlight devrait vous int√©resser. Des actions que vous r√©p√©tez pourtant sans arr√™t... Jusqu'au moment o√π le jeu vous dira merde, non, cette fois √ßa marchera pas, prend √ßa dans ta gueule. C'est un peu frustrant. Retrouvez toutes mes critiques sur SensCritique ![www.senscritique.com]Je ne vais pas √©crire une critique compl√®te du jeu, l'ayant d√©j√† fait pour le titre initial Ghostbusters: The Video Game. Car comme mon titre l'indique, nous avons √† faire √† un remaster fain√©ant.Pour celles et ceux qui ne le savent pas ou qui m√©langent les termes, une remasterisation est une refonte d'un jeu. D√©j√†, vous pouvez oublier une am√©lioration du gameplay, il n'y en a pas. Le contr√¥le du personnage est identique √† l'ancien titre, ce qui est dommage car sans √™tre ignoble, on ne peut pas dire que ses mouvements sont fluides.Par contre j'ai rencontr√© un bug r√©current, que je n'avais pas dans l'ancien titre. Si avec Ghostbusters: The Video Game il arrivait de rares fois qu'un fant√¥me se bloque dans le d√©cor. Ici, les fant√¥mes se bloquent tr√®s souvent hors de port√©e. Ils sont l√†, vous balancent des merdes, mais ils restent immobiles et vous ne pouvez les atteindre...Vous compterez alors sur l'IA, qui n'est pas meilleure qu'auparavant, pour r√©ussir ce qui est impossible pour vous : faire revenir ce foutu fant√¥me sur le terrain !Bon par contre ne r√™vez pas, vos co√©quipiers sont toujours aussi lents pour vous relever lorsque vous √™tes √† terre du coup comme avant, ils ne r√©ussiront pas √† venir vers vous sans se faire mettre √† terre aussi, vous obligeant √† reprendre au dernier checkpoint.La seule "am√©lioration" que vous trouverez concerne les graphismes. Mais mis √† part le fait que ce remaster est jouable en 4K √† 60fps, la refonte est douce, comme le prouve cette vid√©o comparative.Je le recommande tout de m√™me car √ßa reste un plaisir de d√©couvrir le tr√®s bon sc√©nario offert par ce jeu qui reste quand m√™me tr√®s agr√©able dans son ensemble. Et comme j'ai pu le dire pour le titre initial, il ravira les fans de la licence. Mais si vous avez le titre initial justement, vous n'aurez pas besoin de celui-ci. Si ce n'est pas le cas cependant, attendez une baisse de prix. Il co√ªte 21‚Ç¨ mais se retrouve souvent en promo √† 5‚Ç¨.

Temtem est un Pok√©mon-like qui vous fait r√©aliser ce que vous attendez dans un jeu Pok√©mon. Car si Temtem est aussi enfantin dans son histoire que son concurrent direct et propose un contenu identique, ce jeu est cependant bien plus difficile et offre des √©l√©ments que l'on attend dans chaque nouveau jeu Pok√©mon.Le syst√®me de base est familier : vous √™tes un gosse pr√™t √† partir √† la chasse aux Temtems. Pour d√©buter votre aventure, le scientifique de votre ville vous offre votre premier Temtem, que vous choisirez selon les trois qu'il vous propose. Un autre gamin est pr√©sent, qui se r√©v√®le √™tre votre rival. D'ailleurs, il vous mettra une branl√©e direct apr√®s. Le message est clair : les combats ne seront pas si simples, on y reviendra. Ainsi commence l'histoire principale, qui aura une dur√©e de vie allant jusqu'√† 50 heures. Vous ferez face √† un clan aux plans machiav√©liques, pourrez capturer 164 Temtems diff√©rents, combattrez 8 ma√Ætres de dojo... √áa ne vous rappelle rien ?Mais Temtem propose aussi son lot de qu√™tes secondaires, qui vous m√®neront par-ci par-l√† √† travers les diff√©rentes √Æles que propose le monde afin d'accomplir des objectifs divers et vari√©s. Et le tout jouable enti√®rement en coop√©ration !Vivre une aventure de ce genre avec un ami est ce que tout fan de Pok√©mon attend depuis toujours. C'est un r√©el plaisir, et permet de pimenter les combats. Car comme dit plus haut, ces derniers ne sont pas simples. Chaque combat se joue en 2 contre 2. Si en solo, vous aurez une √©quipe de 6 Temtems et en enverrez deux en m√™me temps, en coop√©ration chacun des joueurs enverra un Temtem au combat, et utilisera au total 3 Temtems de son √©quipe. Si chaque Temtem a un ou deux types, permettant donc des r√©sistances ou des faiblesses, peut apprendre 4 attaques, peut tenir un objet et poss√®de un trait qui lui est propre, il aura une barre d'√©nergie. Cette derni√®re se videra au fur et √† mesure de vos attaques, et si jamais elle est vide, alors votre Temtem sacrifiera de sa vie pour attaquer, avant d'√™tre √©reint√© pendant un tour. Cela donne une autre dimension aux combats, et permet alors un v√©ritable challenge. De plus, certaines attaques peuvent profiter d'une synergie, c'est-√†-dire que l'attaque sera plus puissante si le Temtem combattant aux c√¥t√©s de l'attaquant est du type d√©sir√© par la synergie. Et croyez-moi, les dresseurs qui seront sur votre route jouent sur la synergie et sur les types pour √™tre plus efficaces.Le PvP √©tant bien √©videmment possible, vous vous doutez que les combats comp√©titifs peuvent prendre une ampleur √©norme.Ainsi, pour monter une √©quipe parfaite, il vous faudra faire preuve de patience et capturer des Temtems ayant de bonnes statistiques. Ces derni√®res sont au nombre de 7, et peuvent profiter de bonus via les CA et les CP. Chaque statistique peut avoir un montant maximum de 50 CA, ce qui donnera 25 points bonus √† la stat concern√©e. Pour obtenir ce montant, il faut soit capturer des Temtems ayant 50 points de base dans une ou plusieurs statistiques, utiliser des objets ou les faire se reproduire. Ce point est aussi plus approfondi que dans Pok√©mon, on y vient juste apr√®s. Les CP quant √† eux peuvent √™tre de 500 maximum dans une stat, et chaque Temtem ne peut avoir plus de 1000 CP. 7 CP donnent un point dans la statistique concern√©e, ainsi un Temtem peut avoir 71 points bonus dans deux statistiques ! Pour augmenter le nombre de CP, il faudra faire combattre son Temtem face √† des Temtems sauvages sp√©cifiques, qui donneront quelques points √† une stat pr√©cise.Je vous laisse imaginer le temps que √ßa peut prendre... Si en plus vous voulez que votre Temtem soit luma (l'√©quivalent de shiny), il vous faudra √©norm√©ment de chance en prime !Pour vous aider dans l'obtention des 50 CA par statistique, la reproduction est possible. En faisant s'accoupler un Temtem m√¢le et un Temtem femelle, vous pourrez transmettre aux b√©b√©s des attaques, des traits et les CA tant d√©sir√©s. Mais cela n'est pas sans condition. Pour que deux Temtems puissent se reproduire, ils doivent √™tre jumeaux ou partager un m√™me type. Sachant que si les deux ne sont pas identiques, le Temtem √† na√Ætre sera de la lign√©e √©volutive de la m√®re. De plus, chaque Temtem ne peut se reproduire que 8 fois maximum, et cela baissera au fur et √† mesure de vos reproductions. Ainsi, la capture de nouveaux Temtems sera n√©cessaire si vous n'arrivez pas √† obtenir votre compagnon parfait rapidement.Si depuis quelques ann√©es les jeux Pok√©mon permettent d'habiller votre personnage, Temtem le propose aussi. Mais que ce soit cela ou la cr√©ation de personnage, √ßa reste du basique malheureusement. Par contre, si le visage de votre personnage semble normal, les visages des PNJ sont affreux. Ils sont plats, sans reliefs. Ce qui leur donne un air ahuri...Par contre, vous pouvez vous acheter une maison et la d√©corer. √áa n'apporte rien, mais on adore √ßa !Un contenu endgame permet √† plusieurs joueurs de rejoindre une antre tous ensemble. Ils devront alors se frayer un chemin jusqu'√† la fin de celle-ci, en combattant et en r√©cup√©rant des ressources, avant d'avoir √† combattre ensemble un Temtem mythique. Ce qui permet d'obtenir le Temtem en question, ainsi que des r√©compenses sp√©ciales.En bref, Temtem propose ce que les jeux Pok√©mon ont aussi, mais de mani√®re plus approfondie et sans vous tenir la main tout du long pour faciliter les choses tout en apportant des aspects in√©dits au genre. Mais √† la diff√©rence que le jeu est encore en acc√®s anticip√©, et que du nouveau contenu est d'ores et d√©j√† pr√©vu. Prochaine √©tape : l'ajout de montures !Par contre on regrettera le choix de l'√©criture inclusive. Lire des conneries comme "iel" ou "maon", c'est d'une d√©bilit√© sans nom.Retrouvez toutes mes critiques sur ma page SensCritique.[www.senscritique.com]

Lorsque le studio Telltale Games √©tait √† l'apog√©e de sa carri√®re, les d√©veloppeurs encha√Æn√®rent les sorties, tapant dans des licences connues et √† la mode offrant parfois d'excellentes histoires comme leur premi√®re saison de The Walking Dead ou le g√©nial Tales from the Borderlands, des histoires int√©ressantes comme pour leur jeu sur Game of Thrones et la seconde saison de The Walking Dead et parfois des catastrophes comme 400 Days ou Michonne...Alors en visant Minecraft, √† quoi pouvait-on s'attendre ? Je veux dire, bien que ce ne soit pas un jeu qui a pour vocation de narrer des l√©gendes de son univers, √©norm√©ment de cr√©ations de fan ont pris de l'ampleur, au point de devenir des romans ou des bande-dessin√©es.Mais c'est toujours plut√¥t enfantin... Et c'est le cas ici aussi.Le sc√©nario, sans √™tre tr√©pidant, se montre simple. Il se d√©couvre une fois, mais ne vous attirera pas pour une seconde d√©couverte, non, m√™me pas pour d√©couvrir les r√©sultats de choix diff√©rents de votre premier passage.Par contre, chez Telltale Games ce sont des enfoir√©s ! Il y a UN moment triste dans ce jeu. Et ils m'ont fait rire pendant. C'est diabolique !Le monde de Minecraft est respect√©, que ce soit dans le bestiaire ou encore ses biomes, mais il est logique que d√©couvriez des choses qui n'existent pas dans le jeu initial. Pas d'inqui√©tude, cela ne d√©nature pas l'univers !Mais les d√©veloppeurs ne prennent une fois de plus aucun risque et nous offre un jeu identique aux autres.On n'a pas l'impression que les choix ont un v√©ritable impact sur la suite de l'histoire, les QTE sont omnipr√©sentes, mais ne suivent aucun rythme et il y a encore et toujours ces passages inutiles dans lesquels vous devrez faire faire trois pas √† votre personnage avant de d√©buter une nouvelle cin√©matique...La seule nouveaut√© est le fait que vous pouvez choisir d'incarner un homme ou une femme.C'est peu.Si vous √™tes un grand joueur de Minecraft, un fan absolu, un mordu de d√©couverte, ce jeu pourrait vous plaire.Si cet univers ne vous parle pas sp√©cialement, peut-√™tre devriez-vous vous diriger sur un autre titre...Retrouvez mes critiques sur SensCritique ![www.senscritique.com]
