APE OUT is a masterclass in game design. This is a small package, but is bursting with clever design decisions and pure unadulterated addictive action. APE OUT is first-and-foremost an arcade score chaser, with a short yet interesting campaign that intends to showcase a series of different ideas. Each idea forces you to adapt and even rethink how to go about things. And every idea in here really works. The artwork is nothing short of brilliant, and is used in many creative ways. For example, the second Disc skyscraper blew my mind. I just loved that. From the color palettes to simple-yet-clear textures to that wicked camera angle - it all creates an exhilarating atmosphere. Moving on. This title makes one of most creative uses of music that I've witnessed in ages. Maybe ever. Yes, it's nuanced and small - but also genius. I was sold with just the jazz level, and then it changed! That marching band 3rd Disc is powerful stuff.  But then we have some more nuance. I was watching the developer live stream, and they made some interesting comments. They mentioned that the rooms don't actually make sense because that's probably how it would feel through the eyes and mind of a confused and rampaging ape. Same idea for how everyone would appear to be an enemy. Now this is also a convenient narrative to excuse proc gen - but I don't care because it's also wildly interesting. And the proof is in the pudding - if there is one thing that is undeniable about this title - you truly do feel like a confused and rampaging ape. You only need the edge of your seat for this one.Pros:+ This is a brilliantly designed game.+ The way the music is implemented is not only as fresh as it gets, but it both sounds outstanding and pairs perfectly with the gameplay.+ This is very addicting.+ Leaderboard support is awesome.+ I find there is a good bit of strategy here; definitely less twitchy than some of it's comparisons.Cons:- We could use some QoL options like the ability to adjust volume while playing.- When I use windowed mode, or really change any resolution settings it usually crashes and logs me out of Steam. I've learned to just not touch things.- The main 'game' is quite short. While what is present is fantastic, maybe they could have added in a bit more. And then again, maybe it's good that it doesn't overstay it's welcome.This is the first great game I've played in 2019. Worth full price.

I've been checking in and playing Beacon on and off for nearly a year now (I purchased on Itch). The same problems and design issues I took with my first experience still persist today. Frankly, as a casual player of Beacon, I couldn't tell you what has actually changed over the last year from just my in-game experiences. The whole thing feels like a case of style-over-substance. Obviously the asking price matters here.Beacon wants to be the next big rogue-ish shooter, but I can't get past some fundamental flaws. First off, a word of warning: controller users are second-rate citizens here. I know the store page claims 'full controller support', but it is very much just emulating the mouse. Some games can get away with this, but not here.  Not with something requiring this much precision. Even the developer recognized and acknowledged it's hard to beat a keyboard and mouse here (in one of my threads on the forum). I only complain about this because it didn't have to be this way. This could have been easily designed from the ground up as a controller-friendly game.The art and aesthetic is brilliantly crafted, but I'm sorry to report that the game itself is just not that much fun. This has all been done before in better ways. The camera angle is decidedly awkward considering you can and will be rolling and falling off the narrow pathways regularly. Clicking for every single shot with the basic pistol is tedious. The developer told me they would consider changing this several months ago, but it still persists today. Finally, the performance has always been, and still is, quite bad. Even with Vsync on, this makes my gaming rig scream. I really don't see why, but it does.Pros:+ The artwork, universe, and overall aesthetic is coolCons:- To a casual observer, the development is really slow- The price-point is too high for something that has essentially been done a million times before- Optimization continues to be poor; will it ever be improved? Who knows- Using a controller hinders you- Combat is uninspired- Awkward camera angle and narrow pathways are not fun for me- I'm just not compelled to play thisI bought into this based on the slick artwork, but from my experience over the past year - this gets a hard pass from me. Maybe there is a hidden gem deep in here somewhere, but I'll never find it due to the issues listed above.

There is a demo, but curiously I don't recommend it. I originally passed on this title after playing the demo, but later bought in after watching a streamer. It boils down to the demo not conveying the whole sandbox aspect.The Coin Game is really neat. The best comparison is to My Summer Car, as said by The Carlz0r. What this means is that while we have a main gameplay focus on earning tickets from arcade games (with individual Leaderboards!), but there is also this whole sandbox going on. You have a fairly large island to explore and do odd and zany things. I delivered papers, got addicted to scratch-off tickets, and found a UFO. Things like that.What I do need to convey is that there isn't all that much content right now. The arcade games are good fun, but there are only a handful at this point. The island is large, but we only have one job of a paper route so far. There is a lot of potential, and I can easily recommend it in the current state for the small asking price, but you should know what you are getting into. I explored just about everything and got the Achievements I wanted all in under 2 hours. But I did have fun. I really hope this gets constantly expanded, because the sky is the limit with this one. It would be awesome to have a large community with Steam Workshop support.Pros:+I love this new niche genre of open sandbox with strange goals+This is quite fun+While there are only a few things to do, they are done right+Individual Leaderboards for each arcade game go a long way hereCons:-Hopefully this project doesn't get dropped, and a ton of content is added over time-There are plenty of rough edges (cars have no AI and just plow through you, arcades glitch out; things like this)Yeah, this is a fun one.

Wraithslayer is an interesting take on the twitch-style arena shooter genre. Like most titles in this niche space (ie. Akane or Tormentor X Punisher), the experience is small, yet potent. The price-point pretty much says it all. If you are compelled to really put your skills to the test, you'll likely get a lot of mileage out of games like this. At this point, I'll buy anything Sean Young is involved in because the projects are always outside-the-box thinking with a more-than-fair asking price. This is no exception.Essentially, this is a single screen bullet hell dodge-em-up with one central boss. You need to collect three 'orbs' and then you can use your body to hurt the boss. Three hits moves you on to the next phase. You die in one hit. The store page boasts 'procgen AI/boss battles', but unless I'm missing something, that is a bit misleading. I haven't found anything 'procgen'. I have found that there is a pool of boss attacks, and what order you get them in seems to be random. Other than that everything is pretty much the same, and that's fine. At first the movement system is super awkward, but after about 30 minutes I was getting much more dexterous with it. The whole thing is fun in a one-more-run kind of way.Pros:+Fresh take on the twitch-style arena games  +The price-point is more than fair+The artwork and music is niceMeh:=The lore fragments are neat, but the story really doesn't feel like it fits the settingCons:-No pause button, and I can't justify that here-I think the term 'procgen' is misleading on the store page-Your mileage really will vary depending on how compelled you are to play this style of game-This is a neat idea that really could have been expanded into a more fuller experienceWraithslayer is a neat and original indie game experience. Worth full price.

I have love for the sequel, but not so much for the original W4RR-i/o-RS game found here. This is very much a glorified spreadsheet with no story, game, or goals. I know that is stated on the store page, and sometimes that kind of system works - but unfortunately not here. And on top of that, the incredibly rough edges are insult to injury.Essentially, you are given a short list of 'warriors' that have a few stats attached to them, and you pit them against each other. The outcome is honestly boring and quite predictable. Each row of the spreadsheet is one warrior. The list of possible input commands is horribly jumbled most of the time due to the limitations of the terminal window in which you are working/playing (and not jumbled in any consistent way, either). Mixing that jumble with some of the artsy use of ASCII and it just comes off broken. You can choose two warriors at random to fight, choose two directly to fight, or make time pass which alters some stats. As-is, the Achievements are quite easy to cheese and most end up being an exercise in spamming keys. It's kind of a shame, because with just a tad more complexity combined with some clever Achievement goals, we may actually have something to work with here. Pros:+ I like the crunchy indie styleCons:- Simply not enough content- No compelling reason to play other than figuring it out - which takes about 5-10 minutes- Achievements could have been a bit more clever- Rough edges galoreI'm glad games like this exist, but this title could have benefited from baking a bit longer.

What a weird little broken toy to figure out. I like it. W4RR-i/o-RS: Descent is a small scope turn-based puzzle game. There is nothing 'RPG' about it, so take the store page description with a grain of salt. There isn't so much a story as there is a few small, abstract, and brief bits of text. The whole thing can be 100%'d in about 2 hours. I'm not going to explain how it works because that is the fun of it; that's what you are paying for here. All I can say is that I found it quite interesting to first figure out how the system works, and then use that knowledge to complete the game. It does get grindy and repetitive towards the end, but hey, you only have to do it once. Pros:+The small entry fee was well worth it+Nice combination of turn-based battles and puzzle elements+It's fresh; there is nothing quite like thisCons:-Rough edges is an understatement-Resizing the window is a major undertaking-The 'music'/sound is terrible-The ASCII artwork is terrible-This could be a base for a much larger game that would be great-It gets grindy at the end-No keyboard shortcuts-One Achievement is broken (or the description is wrong)Yeah, I had a fun afternoon with this one. Cheers to indie games!

Everpath: A Pixel art roguelite has too many issues for me to get behind right now. The artwork is fantastic, but nearly everything else needs a good bit of work. For starters, the movement feels like you are on ice. Yes, I've heard this is going to be worked on - but getting movement to feel right and work right isn't a simple thing. We'll see. Next, there is no controller support right now, and I find WASD plus the number keys to be a chore. You have to push the number keys quickly in the heat of battle, which leaves me wrestling more with controls than monsters. The combat system is overly simple, and is mostly an exercise in spam clicking. Most of my time was spent kiting and circling around enemies. This is a product of small one screen arenas.Again, the artwork and animations are remarkable. I do hope more assets are planned to be added, though. The first three levels were exactly the same, and there really wasn't much variation within them, either. The procgen is very much a tile toss. I fought two minibosses which were the exact same troll. This is the kind of stuff that really needs some TLC and refinement. Will it get there? We'll see.Pros:+Beautiful artwork+The price-point is obviously not an issue; in fact it's too cheapCons:-Movement is bad-Strategy really boils down to circling and kiting enemies-Each screen is an arena that really feels too small, and this is also related to my strategy note above-Managing WASD and the number keys is a chore-While the assets are remarkable in quality, we need more-The procgen level layouts are ho-humI get that my expectations shouldn't be high for a four dollar game. I do get that, and maybe the creator just wants to make a simple proof-of-concept roguelite. If that is the case, then I guess I can't argue. But if the goal is to create something addicting and fun and fresh - then hopefully some of my points above can be useful. I wish the developer the best for a successful Early Access campaign.

Is Comet Crasher the next big thing? Nah, but it's pretty fun, quite addicting - and paying is optional. This is an arcade score chaser that does just enough right to keep me coming back for more. What I'd really like to happen is a sequel with better artwork and some tighter platforming controls. And maybe slight rebalancing that rewards just a tad more skill and strategy. But otherwise this is good stuff.Cheers to indie games!

As far as their work in video games goes - this is hands-down Ridiculon's best soundtrack. They just took some awesome classical music and did all kinds of crazy wonder stuff with it. This runs the gamut from gritty 8 bit jams to some heavy metal ballads. Too awesome. And I have to say that at first I thought the soundtrack was small because I'd keep hearing the same classical themes playing - but there are actually several variations of each song here. In-game I was probably too focused to make mental notes, but it's super obvious when checking out the soundtrack files.Great stuff.

Pocket Rogues isn't particularly bad, and the price-point is surely fine - but it's just too standard in it's design. What we have here is a permanent upgrade system like in titles such as Rogue Legacy or Immortal Redneck, mixed with some vanilla aRPG dungeon crawling. And it's all just a bit too slow for my tastes. It felt like the runs were watered down by being far too easy until you hit a wall. I would prefer a more potent experience where I die sooner and earn more gold in the meantime. Tighter loops; shorter runs. Now I'm sure this is a labor-of-love project with modest ambition - and I appreciate and applaud that. I just don't find it compelling and therefore can't recommend my friends run out and put down their money.While we've been over this before - I have to again reiterate that this particular type of permanent upgrade system is tricky in that it doesn't so much reward skill, as it does grind. You grind to get permanent upgrades and buffs, in turn to grind to get further in the dungeon. It can work, but in general this is my least favorite way to manage upgrades. The upgrades are all standard, too. We have stereotypical upgrades like damage buffs, and classic playable classes. This is an easy and free opportunity to make this title stand out from the sea of dungeon crawlers out there.There are rough edges. Sure, it's an Early Access campaign. I get that. Controller support is pretty wonky right now. Many of the enemy sprites are muddy and really hard to tell what they are. The enemy AI is quite bad (they get stuck on corners and walls). Building your fortress sounds great, but it really just boils down to a tech/skill tree. Level design is nothing special. Again, I'm not trying to hate on a pet project, but all these things add up to something I can live without. Pros:+I can't argue with the price+I do like the idea of a bite-size aRPG rogue-ish gameCons:-There is nothing fresh here-Overly standard dungeon crawler-The enemy artwork is muddy-Controller support needs a good bit of work-The dungeon crawling is a bit too slow, and runs too long for my tastesIt isn't about the money with this one, it's about your time. I do wish the developer the best with this and any future projects - but this gets a hard pass from me.
Short, sweet, charming (and gay). No matter what actions you take, it ends in misery, but you get attached all the same. It's a lot of fun if you're a masochist.
‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, maybe hack-n-slashes aren't for me, even Furi couldn't put me to sleep.

Crashes on the second runtime onwards, and controller support ends there as well (playing on a Dualsense).The gameplay was a nice puzzle, but the music clearly shows the game thinks of itself as some profound indie experience which doesn't work so well when you're a billion-dollar megacorp IP.Overall, 1/10 for immersion and pure technical fails.

Bigger and better, it's improved on Arkham City in every way. Bigger map, a vehicle to help navigate this expanded terrain, and tank fights (and Riddler collectibles) to give it an air of necessity. Anything from the previous games were either kept the same or directly upgraded. Combat is mainly untouched (including Batman's patented Disarm and Destroy), with slightly new enemy variations to be aware of (such as shield brutes). Gadgets and stealth mechanics have been refined, the most obvious examples of each being the Disruptor and Fear Takedowns, the latter of which I've only seen re-used in one other game I've played (Ghost of Tsushima). Gadget cooldowns in general are much saner compared to Arkham City, especially Smoke Pellets being usable more than once per stealth encounter now, so there's no need to be so stingy with those any more.Aside from the odd lategame bug (like glitching after a death in a stealth boss fight and walking, not gliding, off a vantage point while aiming the REC gun), my only complaints were with the storytelling. The Season of Infamy DLC was a wonderful way to wrap up the stories of characters from previous games that fans may have been curious about (especially Mr Freeze), but most of the base game's side missions were map-clearing busywork (some of which I did still very much enjoy) or pointless hunts/chases (both fire missions, hunting Man-Bat, bomb defusals, checkpoints, and watchtowers), which were successful in making Riddler's collectibles seem that much more appealing. You also had one-time missions (involving Jack Ryder or Lucius Fox) that seemed to only exist as filler despite having both been built up as something big, and I do wonder if these missions were shortened as a result of rushed development. I thought the Two-Face, Penguin, serial killer, and Riddler missions were great though, both narratively and in gameplay. The only reason the main story has any more weight than Rocksteady's previous games is due to how heavy-handed they wanted to be about Batman: Arkham Knight being the series' swan song, and unlike with Arkham City, the game's story, gameplay, and general pacing isn't at odds with its theming too, so I stayed immersed easily.Batman's sidekicks seem to have generally been aged down to all be closer in age, with the exception of Robin being aged up. Changing Barbara's voice actress to somebody younger than in the previous games and then making her seem a naive damsel in distress (although admittedly Batman's entire entourage gets kidnapped throughout this game) shouldn't sit very well for any Batman fans. I still wish I could've seen more interactions between the Bat-Family overall. It was fun playing as Nightwing, Catwoman, and Robin in their respective moments tag-teaming with Batman, with their movesets and arsenals from Arkham City being mostly unmodified as well for any players retaining the muscle memory.Altogether I'd say it's an 8/10 game, and I don't recall the last time I spent the best part of a month playing a game so obsessively, nor am I going to stop any time soon.

Improves on everything Asylum did while keeping (most of) what made the first game great. Very good worldbuilding, even if the plot leaves something to be desired.The first game had a variation of 9 combat moves, and this one ups that count to 13, at the cost of heavily nerfing the Batclaw. You get new abilities such as Freeflow Focus, which lets you move faster while enemies move slower (but you can still take damage and lose your Freeflow in this state). For traversal, you get a new Grapnel Boost which lets you glide around without ever having to touch down as long as you have something to boost off of, and there are a few glide-powered takedowns which make street brawls that much more fun to start. There are new enemies, such as armored and shielded enemies, but you still have knife-wielding enemies (taken down a little differently this time), and Titan thugs, who are mainly saved for Riddler's Revenge.Riddler's Revenge is the main blemish on this otherwise-fun game. It's ridiculous that they managed to make collectible-hunting so fun, but then rewarded our efforts with THIS. For completion, the first game only made you complete 4 maps on 2 difficulties for both combat and stealth (totalling 24 medals in each). In Arkham City, you have 24 maps (12 with normal difficulties and score tiering, 12 on extreme), and that's not all. You also have to complete "campaigns", gauntlets of 3 challenge maps in a row where the aim is to earn all 9 medals (earning all possible medals from all maps) in one go. Also unlike the first game, the score tiering is much harsher this time around. For most combat maps in Asylum, the old formula was Silver and Gold tiers being double and triple the Bronze score respectively, but now in Arkham City they're double and quadruple (respectively), making each map much more of a grind. The whole thing seems sadistically designed to punish players, rather than supplement the experience like Asylum's challenges did.
A little messed up, but it was a great way to make us care about pre-established characters (that I previously found annoying).Cw: contains venting, a reference to the prequel, Amogus.

Firstly, the negatives.Timing/flow of combat is wonky, freeflow seems to be inconsistent all-around. I know players claim there's a rhythm to it and that you shouldn't button-mash, but my experience has been the complete opposite.You only have a window of like 1-2 seconds at most to add each successive move to your combo before it expires.Countering only works if you're within the enemy's attack area (so you could be millimetres out of it and break your combo in your attempt to counter because the game decides this time that it won't clip you into countering their move and you're left grappling with thin air)You're told far too late in the tutorial stage that you have to work up to a x3 combo (with regular hits) to enter freeflow to begin with, after numerous skirmishes with Blackgate thugs.The other type of enemy engagement, the stealth, almost feels like an afterthought. There is only one ability upgrade that pertains directly to your stealth moveset, and while more of your gadgets are oriented at stealth sections rather than the open combat/freeflow sections (in which you're only allowed to effectively utilise the batclaw and batarang without breaking combos), the core game (at least in story mode) doesn't have enough of it to make you feel like you get to use them well enough. The predator challenges do somewhat recognise it since their medals demand that you make use of the otherwise-underutilised bat-gadgets.Most boss fights are basically the same, fight a brute hopped up on Titan while his comrades attempt to wear you down. Only 2-3 boss fights are any different here.Being only able to heal by gathering XP, whether from collectibles or beating fights, made progression annoying for most of my first couple of runs at this game. It gets better if you get the hang of freeflow and/or just reload when you take major damage though.And now the positives.Scarecrow and Ivy's boss fights/levels were genuinely FUN boss fights, Riddler's collectibles felt padded but not to the level of, say, a Ubisoft sandbox, and more importantly they were all easy enough to complete without having to use the internet as long as you find his maps, despite whatever he incorrectly claims. Combat is satisfying once you get the hang of it (I recommend practising your available moves in challenge modes if you're not getting frequent high combos in story mode). Mark Hamill absolutely nails his Joker persona as always, but Kevin Conroy's performance wasn't as dramatic as he could've been in the climax, far too quiet.The game radiates machismo, which is very much take-it-or-leave-it as Rocksteady's ideal Batman clearly seems to be one that prefers to primarily solve things with his fists. The game has standard backtracking to older areas with newer gadgets, just as with any Metroidvania. I personally enjoyed this part but I understand that most people typically don't care so much.Bottom line, it's a superhero game with quality beyond games as buggy as are released nowadays, so I'd recommend it to anyone. Has a good amount of replayability in the challenges, which I'm probably gonna try for next.

Turned a casual bird/flight sim from something that sounded conceptually boring into a serene experience. I still come back to this soundtrack on quiet nights, especially Home.I wonder what other beautiful games and music Forgotten Key might've put out if they still existed today. A pity we'll never know.
Zombie game with slow movement. Why are they always so boring?
A happy game by Amanita. You know what to expect.
Trash

My Grandfather smoked his whole life. I was about 10 years old when my mother said to him, 'If you ever want to see your grandchildren graduate, you have to stop immediately.'. Tears welled up in his eyes when he realized what exactly was at stake. He gave it up immediately. Three years later he died of lung cancer. It was really sad and destroyed me. My mother said to me- 'Don't ever smoke. Please don't put your family through what your Grandfather put us through." I agreed. At 28, I have never touched a cigarette. I must say, I feel a very slight sense of regret for never having done it, because this game gave me cancer anyway.

Rescue Team is a casual time and resource management game(RTS lite) by Buka Entertainment. A storm has ravaged Greenfield Island and has left the island(and your property) greatly damaged. Your goal is to earn enough money to fully restore your ravaged property. To earn money you must restore Greenfield island section by section by controlling  a team of workers and pilots . Completing each island section (or level) in the least amount of time can earn you cash bonuses(and gold or bronze trophies).Tough decisions are the hallmark of good strategy games and Rescue Team has plenty of those - Do you restore lumber mills(wood) or delis(food) first to generate resources ? or do you rescue workers to increase  your manpower ? how soon do you restore the helipad to get the helicopter and begin rescuing people ? should you restore the bridge to gain access to more areas or do you remove debris to gain resources and clear more road ? Clever level design compliments the sound strategy to create a satisfying experience. It took me about 10 hours to complete the game with gold trophies for every level - but I am no RTS genius - so there is probably 7-8 hours of gameplay for the RTS inclined - more if you take it casual or are a novice to the genre. The game has decent graphics and a competent soundtrack but does lack option to adjust the resolution.If you want a good casual RTS with solid gameplay and intelligent level at an affordable price then Rescue Team may be the game for you - easy to recommend (this game would be worth twice the price if it included a level editor)

Spirituelle Fortsetzung von Until Dawn, bei dem es um Jugendliche in einem Feriencamp geht, die dort von Monster √ºberrascht werden und dabei auch auf eine mysteri√∂se Geschichte rund um das Camp sto√üen. Das Ganze wird eben in Form eines interaktiven Films pr√§sentiert, bei dem man immer wieder die Chance bekommt, durch Entscheidungen und Quick-Time-Events den Verlauf mitzubestimmen. An manchen Stellen gibt es auch Bereiche, in denen man sich selbst frei bewegen kann.Grafisch ist das Spiel ein Augenschmaus und auch die Story kann sich durchaus sehen lassen.Das Spiel kann mittlerweile auch im Co-Op mit bis zu 7 Personen gespielt werden - hier sollte man nur beachten, dass das Spiel eben nicht wie die "The Dark Pictures"-Spiele von Supermassive auf Co-Op ausgelegt ist und somit nicht parallele Handlungen der Spieler erm√∂glicht. Ein Spieler steuert dann die Charaktere und alle stimmen f√ºr Entscheidungen ab bzw. nehmen an Quick-Time-Events teil.

Borderlands 3 ist grob gesagt einfach nur "more of the same" der altbew√§hrten Borderlands-Formel - Ein Loot-Shooter mit RPG-Elementen und ziemlich derbem Humor. Es macht halt einfach Spa√ü, sich durch die Gegnerhorden zu schnetzeln.Das Gameplay wurde auf jeden Fall noch mal aufgewertet und dieser Teil hat wohl das beste Gunplay der Reihe. Es gibt einfach so viele verschiedene Waffen mit verschiedenen (mal cooleren und mal weniger cooleren) Effekten und Softstats drauf, dass man auch nach dutzenden Spielstunden immer wieder irgendwelche Dinge entdeckt, die man noch nicht gesehen hat.Storym√§√üig hat dieser Teil allerdings die wahrscheinlich schw√§chsten Antihelden der ganzen Serie in der Hauptstory. Die 4 Story-DLCs aus dem Season Pass 1 haben da meiner Meinung nach interessantere und vor allem auch jeweils sehr unterschiedliche und abwechslungsreiche Kampagnen und bieten noch mal einiges mehr an Inhalt und Spielspa√ü.Oft wird am dritten Teil kritisiert, dass gutes Loot - vor allem eben legend√§re Drops - hier zu h√§ufig droppt. Ich empfand das aber ganz im Gegenteil als sehr angenehm, da man immer mal wieder an interessante Waffen kommt ohne speziell daf√ºr grinden zu m√ºssen. Gerade das taugt mir pers√∂nlich n√§mlich gar nicht.Alles in allem ein sehr empfehlenswertes Spiel.

Sehr cooler Puzzler, bei dem man Lego-Klemmbausteine nutzt um seiner Figur einen Weg zu bahnen und verschiedenste R√§tsel zu l√∂sen.Gleicherma√üen auch irgendwo eine "Raytracing Tech-Demo", die sch√∂n zeigt, was man mit dieser Technik so machen kann und wie sie sinnvoll eingesetzt werden kann.Zum Normalpreis meiner Meinung nach definitiv zu teuer (Hier zahlt man wahrscheinlich f√ºr die Lego-Lizenz mit), aber ein sehr unterhaltsames kleines Spielchen, das sich, vor allem wenn man in Besitz einer Raytracing-f√§higen Grafikkarte ist, definitiv lohnt.

Niedliche kurze VN, bei der die Unterwasserprinzessin Takorita beschlie√üt, an Land nach leckeren Speisen zu suchen, da es Unterwasser immer nur Suppe gibt. Das Ganze ist recht lustig inszeniert und ist als kurzes Spiel f√ºr zwischendurch auf jeden Fall empfehlenswert, aber eben auch in unter einer Stunde komplett durchgespielt.

Martha ist also tot. Aber was hat es mit ihrem mysteri√∂sen Tod eigentlich auf sich? Viel mehr soll hier √ºber die Story auch gar nicht gespoilert werden, denn das gilt es in diesem Psycho-Horror Walking Simulator selbst zu ergr√ºnden.Genau wie das erste Spiel von LKA - Town of Light - richtet sich auch dieses vom Inhalt her mehr an ein erwachsenes Publikum mit ernsten Themen und man sollte schon ein bisschen was abk√∂nnen.  Es bietet sich auch an Town of Light vorher zu spielen, da die Story mit der dieses Spiels verkn√ºpft ist.

Recht kurzer Walking Simulator im Psycho-Horror-Stil, der auf wahren Begebenheiten basiert und die absolut miserablen Lebensbedingungen und unmenschlichen Therapien in altert√ºmlichen psychiatrischen Anstalten thematisiert.Der Reiz des Spiels ist vor allem die sehr gute Story, spielerisch ist das Spiel eher guter Durchschnitt und die Performance etwas holprig.

Ghostwire: Tokyo war f√ºr mich pers√∂nlich ein Pflichtkauf, da es von Tango Gameworks ist und die beiden The Evil Within Spiele immer noch zwei meiner Lieblingshorrorspiele √ºberhaupt sind. Dieses Spiel hat mit The Evil Within absolut nichts zu tun aber ist auf seine eigene Art und Weise auch ziemlich cool, WENN man etwas mit japanischer Kultur und Geistergeschichten anfangen kann. Das Ganze ist n√§mlich schon ziemlich cool umgesetzt.Als Akito erleben wir zu Begin des Spiels, wie komplett Japan ausstirbt und wir von einem mysteri√∂sen "Geist" namens KK besessen werden, der uns anscheinend am Leben h√§lt. Und unsere Schwester suchen wir nat√ºrlich auch. So beginnt dann eigentlich auch schon die Reise durch die verlassenen Stra√üen Japans, bei dem man regelm√§√üig auf feindlich, aber auch freundlich gesinnte Geister trifft. Letztere versorgen einen mitunter mit Nebenmissionen, die mal mehr und mal weniger interessant sind.Besonders hervorzuheben ist noch das Kampfsystem, bei dem man sich mal nicht mit klassischen Waffen durch die Gegner ballert, sondern mit "Handgesten", bei denen man Energie verschie√üt. Das ist ziemlich kreativ, wird aber nach einiger Zeit ein bisschen monoton, da man eigentlich immer nur das selbe macht.Ich war pers√∂nlich noch nie in Japan und kann daher nichts √ºber den Realismus sagen, aber die offene Welt ist schon sehr cool in Szene gesetzt, auch wenn sie sich hier und da ein bisschen leer anf√ºhlt - was aber auch irgendwie dem Setting geschadet ist.Kurzum: Ein empfehlenswertes, sehr einzigartiges Erlebnis f√ºr alle die mit geisterhafter japanischer Kultur fernab des Animes ein bisschen was anfangen k√∂nnen.

Absolut geniales Action-Adventure, das von Kratos handelt, der nach seinem Rachefeldzug gegen die G√∂tter des Olymps Unterschlupf im nordischen Reich gesucht hat. Die Mutter seines Sohnes Atreus ist verstorben und gemeinsam mit seinem Sohn macht er sich auf den Weg um den letzten Willen seiner Frau zu erf√ºllen - er begibt sich auf eine Reise zum h√∂chsten Berg im Norden, um dort mit seinem Sohn die Asche seiner Frau zu verstreuen. Atmosph√§risch wurde das ganze herausragend umgesetzt. Das Spiel sieht toll aus, l√§uft nat√ºrlich (mit der entsprechenden Hardware) viel besser als auf der Konsole und die Elemente der nordischen Mythologie wurden sehr stimmig in das Spiel eingebaut. Auch die Entwicklung der Vater-Sohn-Beziehung von Kratos und seinem Sohn Atreus ziehen einen in ihren Bann und man m√∂chte wissen, wie das ganze weitergeht.Bez√ºglich des Kampfsystems sollte man dieses Spiel hier nur sehr begrenzt mit den alten "God of War"-Teilen vergleichen. Man spielt jetzt eben kein Hack & Slay mehr, sondern viel mehr ein Action-Adventure aus der Third-Person Perspektive. Das Moveset der Chaosklingen, die man sp√§ter im Spiel wieder erh√§lt, l√§sst einen hier und da aber in Nostalgie schwelgen.Die zunehmende "RPG-isierung" des Genres geht auch an diesem Spiel nicht vorbei. Kratos verf√ºgt nun √ºber verschiedene R√ºstungsteile, die sich mit den entsprechenden Ressourcen herstellen und upgraden lassen. Die Zeit der roten Orbs aus den Vorg√§ngerspielen ist vorbei.Eine absolute Empfehlung f√ºr dieses Meisterwerk!

Fast 7 Jahre ist es nun her, dass Dying Light 1 erschien. Ich hatte es das letzte mal vor knapp 6 Jahren gespielt, als ich die Erweiterung beendet hatte. Ich kann mich ehrlichgesagt kaum mehr an das Spiel erinnern, ich wei√ü nur noch dass ich es echt gut fand.Und nun haben wir es endlich - Dying Light 2. Und ich w√ºrde behaupten, dass das Spiel so ziemlich alles bietet, was man sich von der Fortsetzung h√§tte w√ºnschen k√∂nnen. Das Parkouring f√ºhlt sich wieder richtig gut an, genau so wie das Kampfsystem und auch die Story, die im Kern aus der Suche des Protagonisten nach seiner verschollenen Schwester besteht, kann sich durchaus sehen lassen, bietet sogar hier und da Entscheidungsm√∂glichkeiten und motiviert zum Weiterspielen. Richtig gut aussehen tut das Ganze dabei auch.Bin sehr gespannt auf die Story-Erweiterungen! Von mir eine klare Kaufempfehlung.

Nettes kleines Spiel f√ºr den kleinen Preis von knapp √ºber 2 Euro, bei dem man mit seiner Spielfigur immer wieder versucht so lange wie m√∂glich gegen die ankommenden Gegnerhorden zu √ºberleben und das daraus gewonnene Geld wieder in Upgrades zu investieren um.... beim n√§chsten Mal hoffentlich etwas l√§nger zu √ºberleben.In jedem Durchlauf erh√§lt man verschiedene Waffen und Relikte, die sich teilweise kombinieren lassen. Zu Beginn schaltet man durch verschiedene In-Game-Errungenschaften noch neue Items und irgendwann dann auch zwei Maps (von denen eine aber eigentlich blo√ü die Startmap mit einer kleinen Gameplay√§nderung ist) frei. Wenn man erst mal alles hat, wird es aber etwas √∂de, da man eigentlich nur noch dem perfekten Build hinterherrennt um dann Geld zu sammeln. Das Ganze hat was von "aktiv gespieltem idle game".Aufgrund des niedrigen Preises und der Tatsache, dass das Spiel momentan noch regelm√§√üig neue Inhalte bekommt, von mir aber auf jeden Fall eine Empfehlung.
Somehow, Rockstar keeps the same old ingredients, adds a handful of new ones, and manages to create a great new recipe, the best game so far.Thanks for stopping by and reading my review.

This game is a miracle, in my whole life not many horror games have made me be in constant suspense throughout my game. The bosses and enemies you encounter during the game seem to be taken from the mind of Tim Burton, with a hint of Lovecraft and Stephen King. The creativity of the developers of this game is something I thought had already died in the industry, I have never been happier in my life. The level design, the ambient sound, the graphics that seem very simple, but at the same time beautifully terrifying, SOUNDTRACK is one of the most beautiful and terrifying things I've heard (highly recommended). The only thing I can say is pretty lazy is the game. Sometimes it gets wrong, and the camera perspective is sometimes frustrating, but you get used to it. This game is a miracle and, of course, a worthy sequel.

Terminal: how to scan, connect, send files, launch scripts, open ports, root network computers, show status.  Scripting: example hacking scripts, scripts for launching scripts, scripts for buying servers.  Running scripts dashboard: how to see what scripts are running on different computers and read the logs.  Micro-level mechanic: that weaken/grow/hack thing.  Macro-level mechanic: idle game with prestige mechanic.  Other things: augmentations, infiltration games, stat-boosting idle activities, how to build up at the start and after first and second prestiges, hacknet, home computer RAM, TOR router and terminal buy store, character stats, and probably many other things.Super Fun Coding Game.

This game is one of the best games I've ever played, the gameplay is stressful and intense and the characters are all very unique and cool, this is a really great game.The co-op mode is really good and your friend can really mess you up, the difficulty settings really are good to adjust the game and gave me quite a challenge to get them right on the highest difficulty.The game isn't that scary though and I didn't feel that spooked out in most of the game but it's still really amazing.I can't wait for the next one in the series!9/10

Really fun game, been playing since 2016 and I've enjoyed it ever since. There is a few issues with the game, but it's what I expect from a Early access game. Community is good, but most prefer to use the game as a chatroom and not an actual survival type game. Though keep in mind, that is only certain servers. The updates have been held for longer recently in hope to improve the quality of updates, so for anything new I'd recommend using the 'dev branch' Also be prepared to meet the youngest set  of Paleontologist's. So far, Ok, let's continue with the review. The only major downside is the lag. It sometimes happens on some servers whether that's the Server not being powerful enough to run the amount of players, or it's due to the game. There would be times when combat is just un-reliable other than that, there's no major issues. It's landscapes are beautiful and the models are amazing (which are being updated every so often).If you love any type of Dinosaur games, I highly recommend this.

10/10.Well, what can I say. After many years of feeling 'bored' with F1 games, they finaly went and hit the nail on the head with this one. Everything we asked for; formation lap, safety car, career mode, helmet customization  has all been added. But not only have they been added, they've been done correctly and not just 'thrown' in. Here's my opinion on different parts of the game.Career Mode:What can I say. I was very excited and eager to start. I was first faced with Character customization, which was simple and yet efficient. Then it was the team selection, Which I'm glad you can choose any team as it makes it more 'personal' rather than being forced your Path.R&D:As we know it, Research & Development was kind of the weakness in the past years. But this time, it brings a whole new meaning, not only do you improve. Other teams improve and even some don't. But...I honestly think R&D is too easy & too early. In my 1st season with Haas & into the 14th race. Toro Rosso was already 3rd Fastest, Which seemed a little unrealistic. But other than that, it's perfect.Safety & Virtual Safety Car:Finaly. it's back! F1 2015 felt rushed without the safety car, although the Graphics was massively improved from 2014 and some will even argue they're still the best to this day for CM. With it completely been re-done, it feels much better. Although at times, it doesn't come out when it should and it comes out when it shouldn't. In my 2 seasons I've only had 1 VSC, so other than it being rare. I can't really give feedback other than it worked great when it did happen.But yeah that's it. The Game is great again. Thanks.

Good game, very chill, needs a more palpable endgame or "game goal" than just surviving (at least for me). I enjoyed the time played but I'm rather biased towards these types of games. Maybe wait for more updates or get in on a sale.

What a great game. The roguelike part is pretty straightforward - you get gold during your runs, you use them between runs to upgrade your lab for better survival in future runs. The gameplay is smooth, mostly you just spawn units and let them do their thing - either explore or stand still to defend your castle. You can also control 1 unit at any given time, I always preferred speed over dps for that, to scout the map fast and destroy lairs as I go. Anyways, get it, the price is ridiculously low for the quality of content, even though you can finish the game relatively fast.

Definitely has that "one more turn" vibe going. If you're intelligent, it's not complicated at all, just read the tooltips/do the tutorial. That said, it has depth and the event system can lead to different outcomes for your nation. I'm playing on the "great" difficulty (highest) and it's not unmanageable, you can tweak a lot of settings for your new game to suit your playstyle, so make sure to check the advanced settings before you start, because that can alter your gameplay drastically.

Small but engaging for it's short playtime. Due to it's price, it's worth the purchase imo. Don't put the chalice in the temple until you have a bunch of swordsmen, it's not for making a new unit, it's for summoning the final boss. Lost my first run that way xD
It's ok, gives what it says will give and if it seems you might like it, you most likely will. Fairly priced for the current content.
My arm hurts.

This game is a masterpiece. If it weren't for my friend, I would never have gotten the game as it didn't "pop up" as something extra interesting for me, even though I've played grand strategy games. I played 1 run in multiplayer and 1 run solo. The events are interesting, funny a lot of the time. You can do so many things, I wouldn't know where to begin, but I'll include a few funny moments from my solo play.Starting the game in 867 as the duchy of Wessex and later forming the British empire, I bought a claim on the entire of Papacy, waged war on the Pope, who excommunicated me. Of course, I won the war, then got a decision option to "return Rome to Pope". Pfft...what drivel is this? Perfect time to make a new faith with myself as the pope and with a tenet which gives me the ability to conquer neighboring rulers. Later down the line, I had a vassal try to blackmail me for a murder my character did while I was playing his predecessor. I tried to imprison him to execute him before having to click on either blackmail options (cause I ain't letting anyone have a hook on me). 95% chance should be enough, right....right? Long story short, over half of my huge empire took up arms against me, about 180k soldiers vs my 55k or so. Thankfully, 100k gold buys a lot of "oomph", so I ended up beating them at the walls of Lunden and in Bordeaux several times. 8 months of smacking them and I had about 60 prisoners in my prison, mostly kings whom now I could force to renounce all claims in the realm - FINALLY some peace in the realm, so it was all a good thing :D Near the end, after forming the Byzantine Empire, I got the option to restore the Roman empire, which I did, cause Romans. I decided to stop playing at year 1192. Can't get much richer with over 700 gold per month, I unlocked all innovations, Almost all dynasty perks. Wars are now just a hassle and due to the sheer size of my realm, the game freezes for a few seconds every 3 minutes or so, so that bit is annoying.And to think my starting problems were trying to produce a male heir and getting: female twins, female twins again and then FINALLY...a gay son.https://puu.sh/ISrpp/0690e5956b.jpg

This game is just wow. I can't remember the last time I enjoyed the story, gameplay, voice acting (best voice acting I saw in ages) and everything else so much. Even the lore is very interesting (you pick up journals which you can read if you want to, they add more depth to the story. You can skip them if you're not the reading type). My only gripe is that you have 4 classes to choose from, but you can only play 3 person co-op. And yeah, it's amazing in co-op.

A truly beautiful game for any fan of the base building genre, with the added pew pew aspect which is very fluid and satisfying. The campaing is set up nicely, with a good storyline and exploration feel. Definitely worth it.

This game is simply magnificent it is a royal battle but with objectives which completely changes from what we already know. Graphic design I think the work is superb we are directly immersed in the atmosphere but what I find too bad is that there are not many weapons in the game and especially that the improvements are limited. What would be great but I think it would be difficult to achieve would be to be able to have skill points issues that we can improve where we want for example if we want to increase strength or agility we choose where to put our skill points. In what I will also see that the developers could add it would be a little more creepy monster like they are glued to the wall or on the ceilings. Last thing I noticed I find it too bad that there is no interaction with doors all the invitations are open which makes it a little too easy to move when someone runs away. Whatever happens this game is just great for early access I hope the developments won't let the development go because it has a lot of potential.

Das ist  kein Review sondern eher als Hilfe gedacht! An alle Leute die meinen das Game unterst√ºtzt keinen Xbox Controller bzw. Probleme haben ihr Gamepad zu benutzen:Ihr m√ºsst das Spiel starten und dann in die Optionen gehen. Dort k√∂nnt ihr dann den XBox Controller ausw√§hlen.Viel Erfolg!

Heute` gesehen das Blitzkrieg 3 im Sale ist und dachte mir f√ºr den Preis kann man sich das ja mal anschauen. Dann habe ich (zum Gl√ºck) gesehen das es diese Woche sogar ein `Free Weekend¬¥ gibt. Gleich mal runter geladen und angefangen zu spielen. Die Grafik finde ich recht ansehnlich und ich konnte sogar die erste Mission anspielen. Dann nach ca. 10 Minuten, freezt das Game und es gab einen Crash to Desktop. Okay kann ja mal passieren, einfach nochmal gestartet. Aber jetzt bleibe ich im Ladebildschrim h√§ngen und komme nicht auf die Server. Bzw. sagt mir das Game bei der Anmeldung:Fehler - Nicht berechtigtIch denke sowas ist an einem `Free Weekend¬¥ eher suboptimal!^^ Tja, schade eigentlich. Ich h√§tte dem Game gerne eine Chance gegeben. Aber anscheinend waren die ganzen negativen Reviews nicht unberechtigt! ( Diverse Gamer berichten von √§hnlichen Problemen!) So wird das nichts liebe Entwickler! Mega Fail! Edit 24.07.2017: Nach einem ziemlich holprigen Start am Free Weekend konnte ich Samstag und Sonntag doch noch einige Stunden spielen und m√∂chte nun mein Review ein wenig anpassen bzw. erg√§nzen:Ich habe die Kampagne mit den Deutschen gespielt und muss sagen das ich wirklich meinen Spa√ü hatte mit dem Game! Das Missionsdesign fand ich abwechslungsreich und auch die Maps waren sehr stimmig und recht sch√∂n anzusehen. Es gibt eine gro√üe Auswahl an Truppen,die durch erledigen von Missionen nach und nach freigeschaltet werden. In den gr√∂sseren/l√§ngeren Missionen gibt es immer wieder mal Zusatz bzw. Nebenaufgaben zu erf√ºllen, die einem neue bzw. besondere Einheiten als Belohnung einbringen. Einheiten die man freigespielt hat, bleiben in der Kernarmee enthalten und gewinnen an Erfahrung.Verliert man im laufenden Gefecht eine Einheit, ist sie nicht ausgel√∂scht sondern vor dem n√§chsten Einsatz wieder verf√ºgbar. Dennoch sollte man immer im Hinterkopf behalten das man nicht √ºber unendlichen Nachschub verf√ºgt!Im Laufe eines Einsatzes bekommt man Punkte f√ºr die man Einheiten aus dem Nachschub-Pool ordern kann. Hat man keine Punkte mehr oder keine Einheiten mehr im Nachschub, kann es ziemlich eng werden. Ich musste ein paar Missionen mehrmals angehen um zum Erfolg zu kommen. Aber alles in allem gab es was das angeht, keine Frust-Momente!Das Game ist bei weitem nicht so Micromanagement-lastig wie die Men Of War Serie. Hat aber leider auch nicht Ansatzweise den Tiefgang eines Company Of Heroes 1&2. Auch wenn mir das Gamedesing soweit gef√§llt, h√§tte ich mir ein paar mehr M√∂glichkeiten gew√ºnscht wie z.B ein richtiges Deckungssystem f√ºr die Infanterie oder die M√∂glichkeit Verteidigungsstellungen errichten zu k√∂nnen. Sch√ºtzengr√§ben k√∂nnen ausgehoben werden aber das wars dann auch schon. Da k√∂nnte mehr gehen wie ich meine! Warum dann ein negatives Review?  Weil es immer wieder massive Serverprobleme gab! Von Freitag bis Sonntag hatte ich wie oben erw√§hnt immer wieder Disconnects, Freezes, CTD`s.Besonders frustiges Beispiel: Bei den gr√∂sseren Kampagnen Missionen kann es vorkommen, das man auch mal eine Stunde am spielen ist. Nach erfolgreichem beenden einer dieser Missionen, gab es ausgerechnet dann einen Verbindungsabbruch. Nach Neustart des Games war dann der Spielstand weg! Auch das Savegame war weg und auch der Kampagnenfortschritt war nat√ºrlich nicht gespeichert! Also alles nochmal von vorne! Immer im Hinterkopf das es wieder passieren kann! Am Sonntag habe ich ausgiebig gespielt und bin auf √ºber 20 Disconnects gekommen ! ! !Ich musste Missionen teilweise 3-4 mal neu beginnen obwohl ich sie eigentlich schon gewonnen hatte! Das geht irgendwie gar nicht! Deswegen: Keine Kaufempfehlung!Edit 22.11.2017: Ich hatte in der letzten Zeit KEINE Verbindungsabbr√ºche mehr! Da scheinen die Entwickler nachgebessert zu haben. Wie kann ich eigentlich die Kampagne neu starten? Also einen neuen Spielstand anlegen? Ich w√ºrde demn√§chst gerne noch mal neu starten, da das Problem mit den Abbr√ºchen und verlorenen Spielst√§nden behoben zu sein scheint.Hat jemand eine Idee wie das geht?

Es ist bestimmt ein cooles Game...	...wenn man es denn ansatzweise fl√ºssig spielen k√∂nnte. Habe` mir einige Let`s Play`s angeschaut und war mehr oder weniger vorgewarnt das es sich hierbei um ein `Hardwarefresser¬¥ handelt. Ich besitze zwar keinen NASA PC, aber bisher habe ich alles soweit fl√ºssig zum laufen bekommen.  BF4, Far Cry 4, Dying Light etc. l√§uft alles stabil bei 40-60FPS Kurz zu meinem  System: CPU:Intel i5 3470 4*3,2 GHzGPU: Radeon HD7870 2GBRAM: Kingston Hyper X 1600 8GBMAINBOARD: Gigabyte Z77M-D3HAlso wie schon gesagt, kein NASA PC aber auch nicht grad` uralte Hardware. Ich habe fast 2 Stunden mit verschiedenen Grafikoptionen rumgespielt aber so richtig zufrieden war ich nicht. Stellt man alles auf `low¬¥ oder `medium¬¥ geht sehr viel Atmosph√§re fl√∂ten und es sieht einfach nicht `sch√∂n¬¥ aus. Dazu ruckelt es ohne ende. Teilweise sogar bei `low¬¥. So richtig Freude kommt da nicht bei auf.  Dennoch m√∂chte ich das Spiel nicht negativ bewerten! Denn zum Gameplay kann ich nichts sagen. Aber die Performance ist tats√§chlich √§usserst mies wenn man keine potente High-End-Hardware zur Verf√ºgung hat! Und selbst da scheint es bei einigen Spielern auch Probleme zu geben. (siehe diverse Youtube Let`s Play`s)Sollte das in den n√§chsten Monaten optimiert werden, werde ich dem Game ggf. noch mal eine Chance geben. Zum Herbst steht ein Graka-Update bei mir an. Aber mir meiner HD 7870 ist das nix!Wirklich Schade, denn was ich so an Videos`s  und Let`s Play`s gesehen habe sah wirklich vielversprechend aus!Deswegen ist diese Review auch eher an diejenigen gerichtet die √§hnliche Hardware wie ich verwenden. √úberlegt euch das gut, es sei denn ihr wollt ne`Diashow auf eurem Bildschirm sehen!^^Allen anderen bei denen es gut l√§uft w√ºnsche ich weiterhin viel Spa√ü mit dem Game! Ach ja nochwas:Ich habe von dem neuen R√ºckgaberecht gebrauch gemacht welches ja seit kurzem angeboten wird. Hat alles schnell und reibungslos geklappt! Danke daf√ºr Valve! ;-)

So many lies and broken promises. Every trailer above is steeped in missing content. The game itself is almost unplayable. Broken hitreg, AA can't lock on, invisible enemies, broken revives, disappearing guns and to top it all off nobody plays anymore. Less than 4,000 PEAK player count. Go play Battlefield 5, 4, or even one... Hell, Hardline is a better Battlefield than this crap. The game modes are all trash. No, really...Hazard Zone is dead on arrival with nobody actively playing the mode anymore. Why? No real rewards. You grind for a chance at using better weapons next time you play. That's it. No carry over to other modes. No cool skins, persistent extraction inventory, or anything that would make it "the next Tarkov" like they had advertised. Portal could have been great... but they decided to immediately nerf XP gains, weapon progression/unlocks, and what you can do with the engine. Why give people the ability to custom make whatever game mode they want and then, upon seeing what 90% of the community wants, disable that content? Because EA. Conquest is no longer conquest. With points broken into subdivided B1, B2, B3... B15, etc. there's no coordination on the team. It's effectively just a large scale deathmatch with people running around purposeless, just gunning for those kills. It really caters to all the sweaty streamers that only play this game for their clippable moments. Nothing to do with the tactics or actual gameplay that made this mode great. Breakthrough... oh breakthrough... The devs thought it would be a good idea to put a point on top of a skyscraper with only two elevators up and allowed the defending team to drop tanks on the roof. You can imagine how that panned out. Took them months to fix it. DICE devs went full on glue eater on this one. I could literally write a book on everything broken in this game and some people have on the bf2042 subreddit among other places. I will NEVER purchase another EA title so long as I live. This game has indelibly stained forever my opinion of both this franchise, AND EA as a publisher. The level of cash grab abandonware is unparalleled here and that's saying a lot considering the early access plague of cash and dash developers out there... 0/10, I've played flash games better than this
Great game that continues to update and add cool new features to a strange but fun online experience.

Regardless of your build, this is a great utility for locking down your game to squeeze out a little more juice for your gaming session. I strongly recommend the RAM utility as well since it helps free up memory leaks from those wonderful Early Access games Steam keeps selling me.

Let me preface this by saying I don't write reviews often but given the current state of the game I felt it necessary. There are a lot of liars and review bombers here that STILL have an unreasonable hatred for the game after its disappointment at release. The amount of salt is unreal and needs to be corrected. This is what the current game offers from my perspective:Dialogue: Those comparing it to Fallout 4 and saying 76 isn't as good and is empty/boring are full of s***. The back and forth dialogue with the protagonist often gives you 5-8 options for what you're going to say back with varying degrees of karmic consequence as well as snarky attitude. Not only that, many of these are actual SPECIAL checks that you can only pass if you have a higher (or lower in some cases) point value than noted. I've played EVERY fallout since release and this is the most robust dialogue system the franchise has ever seen. Comparable at times to New Vegas and hard to distinguish between. Plot: The storyline is compelling and actually fun. The devs crafted it in such a way that if you're a long time player, everything is level adjusted to match you and the game actually takes your progress in Appalachia into consideration. Without spoiling anything, there are some major achievements you make in the year one story that now come into play in Wastelanders. If you're new, then guess what? You have a little bit of extra work to do but it's made to be easy and seamless so that it doesn't feel like a burden or like you're playing catch up for hours. Regardless of prior experience you're still experiencing the here and now story. The plot makes sense as to why NPC's have come back now as opposed to over the last year and what's been happening in the mean time in a bigger context. You will WANT to either help the raiders or the settlers as each have their own quirks and ideals regarding Appalachia. Regardless, you find yourself fighting against a common threat: Post Apocalyptic America and all the dangers she holds. Karma/Companions:Based on your faction "karma" level, you will gain options to special crafting, companions that guard your settlement/camp, and vendors that offer special goods. This is much like in previous games where you side with one faction and get their benefits accordingly. I've seen people explicitly lie stating there are no companions. These people haven't played the game clearly and likely couldn't get past their overflowing salt reserves long enough to actually follow through the questline. The karma system is a hell of a grind but it gives the game longevity and reminds me of old school WoW where you did your dailies for a shiny new mount. That said, instant gratification folks, steer away... you have to earn bragging rights here.Multiplayer:76 brings us the first multiplayer Fallout experience and they do it in a way that still respects individual autonomy. What I mean by this is that quest choices are YOURS to make. Dialogue choices are YOURS to make. Even if you play in a party with 4 other people, their choices don't affect you. Everything is instanced in a way that gives YOU time to explore dialogue and say what you want to say, building your own lore and crafting your own story. The nice thing about the world being multiplayer is that there are constantly cycling world events with awesome loot and a great challenge that you can hop into with the world around you. Appalachia seems empty most days if you don't party up and the random chance to run into someone is a nice experience. A trade of emotes and maybe a few items given to low level characters is what makes this community so amazing. The old community is filled with the most friendly people as the salty and immature children that make accounts just to leave negative reviews are long gone. Good riddance!Absolutely silly fun:Honestly the best part of this game is just what's kept me playing for so long now... silly deaths, stray grenades, stealthy deathclaws in the night, and drunken Vintage Nukashine adventures. Playing with friends gives you the opportunity to enjoy some of the most random sandbox RPG fun around. You don't know what's over the next hill and you never will. You need to go get an egg for a quest only to find out it's from a deathclaw nest and you get slaughtered while your friends watch laughing? That's the point. Your failures and glory are public for all to see. I've watched people charge a sheepsquatch at level 20 with a baseball bat and get flung into the next state... I've laughed so hard I died too over the range of skill and experience the player base has. Add to that the ability to craft your single settlement and make it whatever you want for the world? Are you a farmer? A vendor? An Innkeep? A hermit living in a hut of creepy crawly nightmares? That choice is yours to make!Fallout 1stI will add to this the biggest contention people have had which is Fallout 1st. The program is a robust offering of Atoms, special skins, emotes, and other bonuses much like in Elder Scrolls Online's monthly program. Add to that you can play on private servers if you want to enjoy the game as a single player/friends only experience. Is any of this necessary? No. Is it even optimal? No. I'd personally rather play online with many other players who can access my vending machines and pay caps for my excess loot, or play in the global public events that take place across the map with a crew of random folks that want to join in (they're usually way too hard while solo)!  Still, Bethesda offers it as an option for those that want to add a little bit extra to their game. It's $15 a month (not $100 like the whiners keep touting which is actually the full year long membership) and is there to expand your game just that extra degree. Don't want it? Don't bother! You still have absolutely EVERYTHING the game has to offer for free.ConclusionIn the end, the devs have given us EVERYTHING the community has asked for and crafted us an altogether outstanding experience. What's more is they've given us Fallout and Fallout 2 AND a Steam copy of the game for FREE (until 4/28/2020) just for owning it on the Bethesda launcher. Things they didn't have to do but did. Take some time to look at the accounts of those posting salty reviews on here. See how long they've been steam users, or how many other reviews they've left. Take their reviews with a grain of salt because they've been whining in Reddit forums for months that as soon as this hit steam they'd do what they're doing now: b**** and moan. This game may have been garbage at release but Bethesda has worked tirelessly to make this an experience worth playing and it ABSOLUTELY is.This game gets a solid 10/10. Would recommend.

Extremely fun and challenging. Character skills and passive tree perks are abundant. There is SO much freedom to build the exact type of character you want instead of worrying about the cookie cutter builds of other Diabloesque games. You will find yourself continually learning well beyond the end of the game and into the epilogue. The variety of endgame content at this point does not disappoint either. There is a multitude of maps, delves, and other activities to keep you fighting and grinding for sweet sweet loot.Not only is the gameplay chock full of content, but so is the loot. There are more top-tier items than you would expect from a game like this. In other Isometric dungeon grinders I've found myself getting the same old legendaries/uniques over and over and over again. Throwing them away for crafting dust etc. Not here. Nearly every single legendary I get is something new and something to spin my imagination around in terms of what I build I could make that would revolve around this piece or what other legendaries might synergize. Voice acting and storyline are phenomenal. You really don't expect some of the twists and turns the game throws at you and through the main campaign you really get a sense of how f***ed up the world is here. This is not a studio that spared expense on details when it came to any aspect of the game and every Act unlocks a new means of gaining loot, or spending it and seems purpose built to give you the tools to become a master of this world. The microtransaction shop is strictly for cosmetics and extra storage space but man oh man are the cosmetics plentiful. While a bit on the expensive side, they're still completely optional and playing in leagues actually awards you with limited time cosmetics just for playing through the content. You don't have to spend a dime on this game to enjoy it but honestly, it delivers SO MUCH MORE than other games in the genre that I honestly couldn't fathom not wanting to support the devs in some way. This game is easily worth a $60 price tag, but it's free. It's FREE. Like... what? You'd have to be insane to not get this game.

Buggy and crashes often but it's early access. That's bound to happen and I see the potential in it. If the Devs focused on those bugs a little more it could easily be one of the most enjoyable pirate based sandbox games out there!
Surprisingly great game that is replayably fun and fosters creativity round after round!

This game shows the polish, potential, and continual development that you would expect from an experienced development studio and yet I've never heard of them. They consistently pour out content, adding further value to a game which, in all honesty, I can't tell apart from many of todays top releases. Plain and simple if the developers decided to stop developing this game, I'd be fine with it since it's complete as is, but rather their dream is bigger than my expectations and they continue to bring me new dino's, new items, new mechanics, more bugfixes (despite only having encountered one CTD during my time on this game) and just a level of enjoyment I haven't seen in ANY other early access titles. TL;DR I enjoy this game enough to shell out more of my money every month to rent a server it's so friggin good.

Let me preface this by saying TL;DR? Go to playstarbound.com and see exactly how amazing this game and its devs actually are.There are a lot of people complaining about this game so let me set the record straight. There are many people who buy early access because it's a fad, simultaneously expecting great finished products with tons of content, not remembering the days of Minecraft alpha or what it truly means to be early access. That being said, this game is not complete (though is more than functional at this point and has more content than most early access games) but it is CONSTANTLY being developed and EVERY SINGLE DAY I DOWNLOAD AROUND 200MB OF NEW CONTENT. That's not only the definition of early access but the model of what it means to be such. So why is it people complain? The early access community sucks.Proof of this is that only a handful of negative reviewers here have bothered to actually go to the developer website. If they had, they'd realize exactly how much additional content is being added every day and would have no reason to downvote this game. The rest find it impossible to navigate to a beta selection tab and choose the nightly branch. That or it's too much trouble for their fat little trollhard fingers to carry their girth that far. It's a beta selection tab, not a trek into the depths of mordor. The official website, playstarbound.com, tracks the nightly development of starbound along the way with updates that range from small stability issues to massive additions of buff systems and items as well as dungeons and biome adjustments. SO why the confusion? If people actually managed to pull their heads out of the tight little crevice of ignorance they keep on their backside, they'd have been following the developer site and found that you have to opt in to "nightly" builds. This was created roughly ten months ago so players had the choice of a STABLE, no new content branch that didn't risk save file corruption, or the ability to play through oodles of new content in a less stable form. But again, the forum debate that discussed this choice (that lasted for months) and the repeated news updates discussing the devs future plans, were probably missed by the trollhards in a year long battle with severe retardation. Rather, children, and I reiterate children, with a McDonald's mentality toward early access products have flame posted forums and complained in steam reviews when it's as simple as selecting a different beta version. If you want daily content and to interact with the devs (who consistently accept advice on content updates on their website) then opt in to the nightly branch and participate in their forums like a decent member of a community.If you want a ten month old version of the game (which is a COMPLETE and FUNCTIONAL version of starbound) then don't opt in to anything. Just don't cry that you aren't receiving updates. You only have yourself to blame for playing the OLD version of the game.There is something for everyone here, and plain and simple, you will enjoy hundreds of hours of gameplay if you manage to actually engage yourself with the devs and the forum community on the main site. You will explore worlds, see things you never would have expected, stumble upon dungeons, fight bosses, and find yourself laughing at many of the unique items scattered across a universe which is so huge that you will NEVER explore even half the planets available. There just isn't enough time in your lifespan for it to be possible.

Pros:-Nostalgic 80s hits mixed together with the original soundtrack-A ton of references to pop culture -Fun gameplay-Good voice acting-Team banter is great-Interesting story-Gorgeous graphicsCons:-Some environments lack depth-Few minor bugsHighly recommend this game for everyone, especially for MCU fans.

When I was a kid, I always dreamed of an open-world dragon ball game in which you can play not only Goku, but also Vegeta, Piccolo, Future Trunks, and out of every dragon ball game before it what I played, this game is truly the one that captures the story and overall essence of my favorite anime tv series.Pros:- Full 4  major playable sagas.- The game has a beautiful graphic style that looks like anime.- Good combat system.- In combat, you can transform into super saiyan 1-3- Semi-open-world game with classic dbz locations.- Multiple playable characters.- Amazing soundtrack.- You can collect dragon balls and wish for money or resources.Cons:- Too many loading screens.- Dialogue is super repetitive. Every time you fly by an enemy or you are collecting resources character repeats the same line over and over.- Boring side quests.- Game offers no challenge.

Despite the game being released in 2013  game still looks amazing combined together with an Interesting story but with a lot of unanswered questions, unforgettable characters like Elizabeth, and amazing voice acting.But if you are not interested in story and characters and only interested in gameplay I don't recommend this game for you because the gameplay is too repetitive.  After few hours of running from one place to another killing all enemies and plus at the same time, you are locked up to the possibility of carrying only 2 weapons at the same time I found gameplay too repetitive and boring.

This game is amazing and I am in love with it. It's a very polished game with an engaging story, interesting characters, memorable moments, and an amazing soundtrack. Arthur Morgan for me definitely became one of the best protagonists of all time. A well-written character with a tragic story who becomes more than just an outlaw.But the game also has some problems... The wanted system is hit or miss, broken economy but for me biggest disappointing thing was the game design. Rockstar created this huge open-world game with a ton of things to do like hunting, fishing, exploring, robbing, and killing, but when it comes to story missions it's super linear aka follow the yellow line. You can't approach a mission differently, you always need to do what the game says you to do and if you do anything other than what the mission said you to do, the mission failed. Approach the enemy from another angle? Mission failed. Take a different route? Mission failed. Mount your horse, go there, kill everybody and repeat over and over. I loved the story in this game, but some exciting story missions for me were outweighed by this repetitiveness and lack of freedom.It's definitely worth its price and I highly recommend this game for everyone who loves exploring and slow-paced games.

Despite game bugs, basic AI, awful police and traffic system, and no cosmetic system (no hair stylists or tattoo artists, etc.) I loved every minute of it. Devs put o lot of love into this game with an amazing story, interesting side missions, memorable characters, and a ton of easter eggs and references. The devs definitely needed more time to finish the game but the people running the company gave devs impossible deadlines so the game released in an unfinished state. I just hope cdpr won't release any paid dlc and multiplayer without fixing all the problems and adding missing features because then they definitely will kill all reputation that has left...

Nachdem ich in das Spiel jetzt ungef√§hr 80 Stunden Spielzeit investiert habe und nun mit der Hauptstory durch bin werde ich einfach mal eine Review dazu verfassen und erl√§utern warum es f√ºr mich das beste Spiel dieses Jahrzentes ist und warum ich mir sicher bin dass da nichts mehr kommt was es toppen k√∂nnte! Erstmal, das was das Spiel f√ºr mich zu einem unvergesslichen Erlebnis gemacht hat: Die Story und Charaktere: Witcher 3 schafft es auch Leuten die weder die vorherigen Teile gespielt haben oder die B√ºcher gelesen haben, die Charaktere ans Herz zu legen und hass gegen andere aufzubringen. Und wenn ich hass schreibe dann meine ich wirklich HASS! Es gab so viele Momente, ob in Nebenquests oder in der Hauptstory wo ich geflucht habe, dass ich dieses Spiel hasse und es gleichzeitig doch liebe, oder wo ich erstmal pausieren musste um zu realisieren was da gerade passiert ist oder was ich da gerade gemacht habe. Die Story ist schon nach ein paar Spielstunden klar und man wei√ü gr√∂√ütenteils wie sie verlaufen wird, trotzdem schafft sie es mit vielen kleinen unvorhersehbaren Momenten einem den Atem zu nehmen.Die Spielwelt: Es gibt nur einen Ausdruck, geil! Es gibt soviel zu entdecken und zu machen! Die Welt ist vollgestopft mit Secrets, Monstern und soviel anderem Zeugs, dass man mal eben 200 Stunden darin versenken kann.Sound/Synchronisation: Ich hab das Spiel auf Deutsch gespielt, nicht weil ich kein Englisch kann, sondern weil ich die deutsche Synchro echt gut finde, die Stimme von Gerald, Yennefer und den ganzen anderen Hauptfiguren sind echt gut vertont, auch wenn der Text manchmal nicht grade den Untertiteln entspricht. Die Musik hilft sehr gut zur Atmosph√§re bei, egal ob bei einem sch√∂nen Sonnenuntergang oder im Kampf.Grafik: Ich h√§tte das Spiel auch in Ultra spielen k√∂nnen, jedoch bin ich eine 60 fps Hure und habe es deswegen nur auf hoch gespielt und nur Sachen wie Texturen und Wasser auf Ultra gestellt, trotzdem sah das Spiel noch total geil aus und lief auf geilomatikon 60 fps, gut manchmal auch 50, aber das war selten. Das Kampfsystem: Es war zwar f√ºr mich ein Grund das Spiel vor einem halben Jahr, nach 3 Stunden in die Ecke zu werfen und zu sagen: "Gott, ist das Schei√üe" Aber die Wahrheit ist: Ich war Schei√üe. Aber ich hab das Spiel zu sehr vermisst und deswegen hab ich vor ein paar Wochen nochmal neu angefangen und mich in das Kampfsystem eingew√∂hnt. Es ist zwar manachmal etwas friemelich aber im gro√üen und ganzen das i-T√ºpfelchen f√ºr ein gro√üartiges Spiel!Aber kein Spiel ist vollkommen perfekt, Witcher ist nur nah dran, deswegen sind hier noch ein paar Sachen die mich manchmal echt gest√∂rt haben. Das Movement: Anfangs hab ich mit Maus und Tastatur gespielt, hab dann aber auf Controller gewechselt, im Kampf ist es zwar in Ordnung aber gerade die wenigen Jump and Run passagen im Spiel sind so gottverdammt nochmal beschissen, sowohl mit Controller als auch mit Maus und Tastatur.Die Bugs: Diese halten sich noch in einem geregeltem Ma√üe wenn man sich mal die gro√üe Welt anguckt. Trotzdem gab es ein paar mal dass ich Aufgrund der Bugs, das Spiel neu starten musste.Pl√∂tze: Es ist ein Plus und ein Minuspunkt gleichzeitig. Wenn man im Sonnenuntergang am Strand den Ausblick genie√üt w√§hrend man zum n√§chsten Dorf reitet ist schon nice. Aber wenn das Vieh mal wieder aufgrund von ein Paar W√∂lfen ausflippt und einen auf den Boden wirft, dann k√∂nnte mans schon wieder zu Lasagne verarbeiten.Fazit: Ich war schon immer ein Fan von Spielen die eine gute einpr√§gende Geschichte erz√§hlen, wie z.B: Heavy Rain, Beyond: Two Souls, Life is Strange oder Until Dawn und Witcher 3 vermischt das Element der packenden Story mit einer offenen Wundersch√∂nen Spielwelt und unterhaltsamen spa√üigen Gameplay. F√ºr mich wie gesagt, Spiel dieses Jahrzehntes! Und f√ºr Leute die das lesen und das Spiel schon durchgespielt haben, hier noch ein kleiner Insider[Vorsicht! k√∂nnte als Spoiler empfunden werden!]FICK DICH IMLERITH!

So, ich werde euch heute mal meine Meinung zu diesem verdammt geilen Spiel abgeben und begr√ºnden warum ihr es euch NICHT, nicht einmal f√ºr 99 cent, kaufen solltet. Also, dann fang ich mal an.Das Spiel habe ich bis jetzt so 20 Stunden gespielt, diese Zeit h√§tte ich auch n√ºtzen k√∂nnen um zu lernen, oder vielleicht andere GUTE Spiele zu spielen, von denen es massig gibt, oder ich h√§tte meine Fresse auf Betonboden schlagen k√∂nnen, das w√§re alles besser gewesen als dieses Spiel zu spielen. Fangen wir mal bei dem Gameplay an, Schei√üe. Oder die Grafik, sehr Schei√üe. Und wo wir grade dabei sind, die Sounds, unterirdisch. Na komm, so schlecht sind die auch nicht, oder? DOCH DAS SIND SIE! SIE SIND SEHR SCHEI√üE. Alles in Allem ist das Spiel ziemlich beschissen, jedoch eine gute Sache hat es, und damit meine ich nicht, dass es nur 99 cent kostet, was viel zu viel ist, sondern der Fakt, dass es einen Spiel Beenden Button gibt. Would close again 10/10.

Although I would argue that the new Hitman games got a lot of things better than Blood Money, I think that this game is the epitome of the Hitman franchise, and the moment when IO Interactive realised just what are they capable to do.Blood Money, just as the new Hitman games (2016 onwards), can be described quite easily: elegant and funny, intelligent and challenging. It is by all means, a stealth game, yet you could say that it's a puzzle which you need to figure out in order to get the perfect kill. Most of the Hitman games have an insane replayability, and this one isn't an exception. You can literally do whatever you want: either be sneaky and try to get the silent assassin rating, try to kill your targets in the most intricate ways or go guns blazing through the level - the game will not punish you. Blood Money is a bit old now, but the Hitman formula is there and it still holds up after all these years. I can also praise the solid story, the incredibly well-fitting soundtrack composed by Jesper Kyd and the good old Agent 47 voiced by David Bateson who is as iconic as Max Payne voiced by James Mccaffrey or Sam Fisher voiced by Michael Ironside.This cute bald killer has a special place in my heart and I might be a bit blinded by nostalgia, but if you are interested in playing the new Hitman games, please give this old gem a try.
